member.name: M:VO.IReadCookie.GetEnum
member.summary: Retrieve the number of items from a cookie object.
member.returns: Number of cookie items (type INT), if successful; otherwise, 0.
member.remarks: This method retrieves the number of stored items for a cookie object.
member.example: See the IReadCookie:GetItem() example.

member.name: M:VO.IReadCookie.GetHasKeys
member.summary: Indicate whether or not a cookie object has keys.
member.returns: TRUE, if the current cookie has keys; otherwise, FALSE.
member.remarks: This method returns a logical value which indicates whether or not the cookie has keys.

member.name: M:VO.IReadCookie.GetItem
member.summary: Retrieve the specified item from a cookie object.
member.param: The name of the variable (item) to to be retrieved.
member.returns: A string value, if successful; otherwise, NULL_STRING.
member.remarks: This method retrieves the specified item, <cItemName>, from the cookie object.
member.example:
The following sample displays the cookie collection of an appropriate request:
GLOBAL goASPComponent AS ASPComponent PROCEDURE InitProc() _INIT 3 goASPComponent := ASPComponent{} CLASS ASPComponent INHERIT IScriptingContext
METHOD HTTPResponse CLASS ASPComponent LOCAL oCookie AS IReadCookie LOCAL aTemp AS ARRAY LOCAL aRet AS ARRAY LOCAL n,i AS INT LOCAL cName AS STRING LOCAL cRet AS STRING oCookie := SELF:Request:GetCookies() IF oCookie == NULL_OBJECT n := oCookie:GetEnum() aRet := ArrayCreate(n) FOR i := 1 TO n aTemp := ArrayCreate(2) cName := oCookie:GetName(i) aTemp[1] := cName aTemp[2] := oCookie:GetItem(cName) aRet[i] := aTemp NEXT ENDIF
cRet := GetHTTPValueTable(aTemp) RETURN SELF:Response:_Write(cRet)

member.name: M:VO.IReadCookie.GetName
member.summary: Retrieve the name of the specified item from a cookie object.
member.param: The number (position) of the item within the cookie item collection.
member.returns: Item name (type STRING), if successful; otherwise, NULL_STRING.
member.remarks: This method retrieves the name of the specified item, <nItem>, from the cookie object.
member.example: See the IReadCookie:GetItem() example.

member.name: M:VO.IReadCookie.#ctor
member.summary: Construct an IReadCookie object instance.
member.param: Pointer to an IReadCookie Interface object structure.
The IServer object instance.
member.remarks: An IReadCookie object instance can be created by the IRequest:GetCookies() method because it is directly associated with an HTTP request. Therefore, you do not have to create this object yourself. Rather, use it for an ASP Component application via the IScriptingContext:Request:GetCookies() method.
member.example: See the IReadCookie:GetItem() example.

member.name: M:VO.IRequest.GetClientCertificates
member.summary: Retrieve the certification fields as a two-dimensional array.
member.returns: Two-dimensional array with name-value pairs, if successful; otherwise, an empty array.
member.remarks: The GetClientCertificates() method retrieves all certification fields (specified in the X.509 standard) as a two-dimensional array. If a Web browser uses the SSL3.0/PCT1 protocol (i.e., URL starts with "https://" instead of "http://") to connect to a server and the server requests certification, the browser sends the certification fields. If no certificate is sent, the collection array is empty.

member.name: M:VO.IRequest.GetClientCertificate
member.summary: Retrieve a value of the client certificate collection of an IRequest object.
member.param: Name of the certificate field.
Position, if more than one variable with the same name, <cVarName>, exists within the collection.
member.returns: A string value, if successful; otherwise, NULL_STRING.
member.remarks: The GetClientCertificate() method retrieves a certification field (specified in the X.509 standard) from the request issued by the Web browser. If a Web browser uses the SSL3.0/PCT1 protocol (i.e., URL starts with "https://" instead of "http://") to connect to a server and the server requests certification, the browser sends the certification field. If no certificate is sent, the collection array is empty and the return value is NULL_STRING.

member.name: M:VO.IRequest.GetCookies
member.summary: Retrieve the cookie collection of an IRequest object.
member.returns: The IReadCookie object instance.
member.remarks: This method retrieves an IReadCookie object instance of the IRequest object.
member.example:
The following example demonstrates the use of this method:
GLOBAL goASPComponent AS ASPComponent PROCEDURE InitProc() _INIT 3 goASPComponent := ASPComponent{} CLASS ASPComponent INHERIT IScriptingContext
METHOD HTTPResponse CLASS ASPComponent LOCAL oCookie AS IReadCookie LOCAL aTemp AS ARRAY LOCAL aRet AS ARRAY LOCAL n,i AS INT LOCAL cName AS STRING LOCAL cRet AS STRING oCookie := SELF:Request:GetCookies() IF oCookie == NULL_OBJECT ELSE n := oCookie:GetEnum() aRet := ArrayCreate(n) FOR i := 1 UPTO n aTemp := ArrayCreate(2) cName := oCookie:GetName(i) aTemp[1] := cName aTemp[2] := oCookie:GetItem(cName) aRet[i] := aTemp NEXT ENDIF
cRet := GetHTTPValueTable(aTemp) RETURN SELF:Response:_Write(cRet)
ASP code:
<% Response.Cookies("mycookie")("value1") = "Hello" Response.Cookies("mycookie")("value2") = "World" Response.Cookies("value1") = "X#" Response.Cookies("value2") = "rules" Set oComp = Server.CreateObject("VoAsp.Component") oComp.HTTPResponse() %>
The result would be:

member.name: M:VO.IRequest.GetForm
member.summary: Retrieve a form value of an IRequest object.
member.param: Name of the form field.
Position, if more than one variable with the same name, <cVarName>, exists within the collection.
member.returns: A string value, if successful; otherwise, NULL_STRING.
member.remarks: The GetForm() method retrieves a form value posted to the HTTP request body by a form using the POST method. If no form value is sent, the collection array is empty and the return value is NULL_STRING.
member.example:
The following example demonstrates the use of this method: GLOBAL goASPComponent  AS ASPComponent PROCEDURE InitProc() _INIT 3 goASPComponent := ASPComponent{} CLASS ASPComponent INHERIT IScriptingContext METHOD HTTPResponse CLASS ASPComponent LOCAL cRet  AS STRING cRet := SELF:Request:GetForm("Value1") RETURN SELF:Response:_Write("Value1=" + cRet) HTML code:
 

Value1:

 

ASP code (response.asp): <% Set oComp = Server.CreateObject("VoAsp.Component") oComp.HTTPResponse() %>

member.name: M:VO.IRequest.GetForms
member.summary: Retrieve all form values of an IRequest object.
member.returns: Two-dimensional array with name-value pairs, if successful; otherwise, an empty array.
member.remarks: The GetForms() method retrieves all values posted to the HTTP request body by a form (via POST method) as a two-dimensional array. If no form values are sent, the collection array is empty.
member.example:
The following example demonstrates the use of this method: GLOBAL goASPComponent AS ASPComponent PROCEDURE InitProc() _INIT 3 goASPComponent := ASPComponent{} CLASS ASPComponent INHERIT IScriptingContext METHOD HTTPResponse CLASS ASPComponent LOCAL aTemp     AS ARRAY LOCAL cRet      AS STRING    aTemp := SELF:Request:GetForms()    cRet := GetHTTPValueTable(aTemp) RETURN SELF:Response:_Write(cRet) HTML code:

Value2:

 

Value2:

 

ASP code (response.asp): <% Set oComp = Server.CreateObject("VoAsp.Component") oComp.HTTPResponse() %>

member.name: M:VO.IRequest.GetItem
member.summary: Retrieve any value of the HTTP request body.
member.param: Name of the variable.
member.returns: A string value, if successful; otherwise, NULL_STRING.
member.remarks: This method returns a value posted to the HTTP request body. The collections are searched in the following order: QueryString, Form, Cookies, ClientCertificate, ServerVariables.
member.example:
The following example demonstrates the use of this method: GLOBAL goASPComponent AS ASPComponent PROCEDURE InitProc() _INIT 3 goASPComponent := ASPComponent{} CLASS ASPComponent INHERIT IScriptingContext METHOD HTTPResponse CLASS ASPComponent LOCAL cRet      AS STRING    cRet := SELF:Request:GetItem("Value1")    RETURN SELF:Response:_Write("Value1=" + cRet) HTML code:
 

Value1:

 

ASP code (response.asp): <% Set oComp = Server.CreateObject("VoAsp.Component") oComp.HTTPResponse() %>

member.name: M:VO.IRequest.#ctor
member.summary: Construct an IRequest object instance.
member.param: An IScriptingContext object.
Pointer to an IRequest Interface object structure.

member.name: M:VO.IResponse.GetExpires
member.summary: Retrieve the current value of the Expires property of an IResponse object.
member.returns: The expires value of the IResponse object in minutes (type LONG).
member.remarks: This method retrieves the current value of the Expires property of the IResponse object. This property specifies the length of time before a page cached on a browser expires. If the user returns to the same page before it expires, the cached version is displayed.

member.name: M:VO.IResponse.GetExpiresAbsolute
member.summary: Retrieve the current value of the ExpiresAbsolute property of an IResponse object.
member.returns: The expires value of the IResponse object as a DATE value.
member.remarks: This method retrieves the current value of the ExpiresAbsolute property of the IResponse object. This property specifies the date at which a page cached on a browser expires. If the user returns to the same page before that date and time, the cached version is displayed. If a time is not specified, the page expires at midnight of that day. If a date is not specified, the page expires at the given time on the day that the script is run.

member.name: M:VO.IResponse.GetStatus
member.summary: Retrieve the current value of the Status property of an IResponse object.
member.returns: The current value of the Status property as STRING.
member.remarks: This method retrieves the current value of the Status property of the IResponse object. The status specifies the value of the status line returned by the server. Status values are defined in the HTTP specification.

member.name: M:VO.IResponse.#ctor

Pointer to an IResponse Interface object structure.
member.remarks: An IResponse object instance is automatically created by the IScriptingContext:OnStartPage() method when the appropriate .ASP file is loaded by the Internet Information Server (IIS). Therefore, you do not have to create this object yourself. Rather, use it for an ASP Component application via the IScriptingContext:Request property.

member.name: M:VO.IResponse.PutBuffer
member.summary: Set the current value of the Buffer flag property of an IResponse object.

member.name: M:VO.IResponse.PutContentType
member.summary: Set the current value of the ContentType property of an IResponse object.
member.param: The general content category.
A specific content type.
member.returns: TRUE if successful; otherwise, FALSE.
member.remarks: This method sets the value of the ContentType property of the IResponse object as a string describing the content type. This string is usually formatted, type/subtype where type is the general content category and subtype is the specific content type. For a full list of supported content types, see your Web browser documentation or the current HTTP specification.
member.example:
The following example demonstrates the use of this method:
GLOBAL goASPComponent AS ASPComponent PROCEDURE InitProc() _INIT 3 goASPComponent := ASPComponent{} CLASS ASPComponent INHERIT IScriptingContext
METHOD HTTPResponse CLASS ASPComponent LOCAL aTemp AS ARRAY LOCAL cRet AS STRING ... SELF:Response:PutContentType(/gif SELF:Response:PutContentType(text/html
RETURN SELF:Response:_Write("Hello world")

member.name: M:VO.IScriptingContext.GetVariantString
member.summary: Helper method to convert a VARIANT string to a X# string.
member.param: Pointer to an IDispatch object.
member.returns: A converted X# STRING, if successful; otherwise, NULL_STRING.
member.remarks: This method converts a VARIANT to a dynamic X# string value. This method can be used to implement ASSIGN methods with STRING arguments.
member.example:
The following sample is a typical implementation of the STRING property, Action, for an ASP Component:
CLASS ASPComponent INHERIT IScriptingContext PROTECT cAction AS STRING
ASSIGN Action(cNew) CLASS ASPComponent SELF:cAction := SELF:GetVariantString(cNew) RETURN SELF:cAction ACCESS Action CLASS ASPComponent RETURN SELF:cAction

member.name: M:VO.IScriptingContext.HTTPErrorMessage
member.summary: Create HTML code to display all values of a X# Error object.
member.param: The current Error object instance.
member.returns: String containing HTML code for displaying the error within an Internet browser.
member.remarks: This method creates HTML code based on the values of a X# Error object, and will be automatically invoked if a runtime error occurs. If you want to modify the default error message design, just overload this method.
member.example:
The following sample demonstrates how to overload the default error handling method to create a customized HTML output: GLOBAL goASPComponent  AS ASPComponent PROCEDURE InitProc() _INIT 3 goASPComponent := ASPComponent{} CLASS ASPComponent INHERIT IScriptingContext METHOD HTTPErrorMessage(oError)  CLASS ASPComponent LOCAL cRet  AS STRING IF IsObject(oError) cRet := SUPER:HTTPErrorMessage(oError) ENDIF RETURN cRet METHOD  HTTPGoBackLink (cCaption)  CLASS ASPComponent LOCAL cRef  AS STRING LOCAL cRet  AS STRING IF !IsString(cCaption) cCaption := "Back" ENDIF cRef := ; SELF:oRequest:GetServerVariable("HTTP_REFERER") cRet += '

' cRet += cCaption cRet += '

' RETURN cRet

member.name: M:VO.IScriptingContext.HTTPQueryString
member.summary: Create HTML code to display all query string items.
member.returns: String containing HTML code for displaying all items of the query string.
member.remarks: The HTTPRequestItems() method creates HTML code to display all query string items.
member.example:
The following source code can be used to create an ASP component for displaying the query string items:
GLOBAL goASPComponent AS ASPComponent PROCEDURE InitProc() _INIT 3 goASPComponent := ASPComponent{} CLASS ASPComponent INHERIT IScriptingContext
METHOD HTTPResponse CLASS ASPComponent LOCAL cRet AS STRING cRet := SELF:HTTPQueryString() RETURN SELF:Response:_Write(cRet)
ASP code:
<% Set oComp = Server.CreateObject("VoAsp.Component") oComp.HTTPResponse() %>

member.name: M:VO.IScriptingContext.HTTPServerVariables
member.summary: Create HTML code to display all environment variables of an Internet server.
member.returns: String containing HTML code to display all environment variables.
member.remarks: The HTTPServerVariables() method creates HTML code to display all environment variables of the Internet server.
member.example:
The following source code can be used to create an ASP component for displaying the server environment:
GLOBAL goASPComponent AS ASPComponent PROCEDURE InitProc() _INIT 3 goASPComponent := ASPComponent{} CLASS ASPComponent INHERIT IScriptingContext
METHOD HTTPResponse CLASS ASPComponent LOCAL cRet AS STRING cRet := SELF:HTTPServerVariables() RETURN SELF:Response:_Write(cRet)
ASP code:
<% Set oComp = Server.CreateObject("VoAsp.Component") oComp.HTTPResponse() %>

member.name: M:VO.IScriptingContext.#ctor
member.summary: Construct an IScriptingContext object instance.

member.name: M:VO.IScriptingContext.OnEndPage
member.summary: Clean up (exit) method for ASP components.
member.remarks: When the server finishes processing the script on an ASP page, it calls the OnEndPage() method for all components that have implemented OnEndPage(). The server calls this method after processing the script on that page. If you want to overload this method for your own de-initialization operation, call the SUPER method first.

member.name: M:VO.IScriptingContext.OnStartPage
member.summary: Entry point for ASP components.
member.param: Pointer to an IDispatch Interface object.
member.returns: TRUE if successful; otherwise, FALSE.
member.remarks: When a user requests a Web page in an ASP-based application, the server calls the OnStartPage() method for all components on that page (except those with application scope). This method creates object instances for following built-in interfaces: ISessionObject IApplicationObject IRequest IResponse IServer If you want to overload this method for your own initialization operation, call the SUPER method first.
member.example:
The following source code shows how to overload OnStartPage() for your own purposes:
GLOBAL goASPComponent AS ASPComponent PROCEDURE InitProc() _INIT 3 goASPComponent := ASPComponent{} CLASS ASPComponent INHERIT IscriptingContext LOCAL p AS PTR
METHOD OnStartPage(pDispatch) CLASS ASPComponent IF SUPER:OnStartPage(pDispatch) SELF:p := MemAlloc(100) ENDIF METHOD OnEndPage() CLASS ASPComponent SUPER:OnEndPage() IF SELF:p != NULL_PTR MemFree(SELF:p) SELF:p := NULL_PTR ENDIF
ASP code:
<% Set oComp = Server.CreateObject("VoAsp.Component") oComp.HTTPResponse() %>

member.name: M:VO.IScriptingContext.WriteImage
member.summary: Create HTML code to display images for ASP components.
member.param: Image file name, including drive letter and path.
member.returns: TRUE if successful; otherwise, FALSE.
member.remarks: WriteImage() creates HTML code for displaying images in ASP components.

member.name: M:VO.IServer.GetScriptTimeOut
member.summary: Retrieve the script time-out value of an IServer object.
member.returns: Timeout value in minutes (type LONG), if successful; otherwise, 0.
member.remarks: This method retrieves the script time-out value of the IServer object in seconds.

member.name: M:VO.IServer.#ctor
member.summary: Construct an IServer object instance.
member.param: An IScriptingContext object.
Pointer to an IServer Interface object structure.
member.remarks: An IServer object instance is automatically created by the IScriptingContext:OnStartPage() method when the appropriate .ASP file is loaded by an Internet Information Server (IIS). Therefore, you do not have to create this object yourself. Rather, use it for an ASP Component application via the IScriptingContext:Server property.

member.name: M:VO.IServer.PutScriptTimeOut
member.summary: Set the script time-out value of an IServer object.
member.param: New time-out value in seconds.
member.returns: TRUE, if the value has been changed; otherwise, FALSE.
member.remarks: This method sets the script time-out value of the IServer object in seconds. This property cannot be set to a value less than that specified in the registry settings. For example, if it is set to 60 and the registry setting contains the default value of 120 seconds, scripts will time out after 120 seconds. However, if <nValue> were set to 200, the scripts would time out after 200 seconds.

member.name: M:VO.IServer._HTMLEncode
member.summary: Apply HTML encoding to a specified string.
member.param: The HTML string to be encoded.
member.returns: An encoded HTML text as STRING, if successful; otherwise, NULL_STRING.
member.remarks: This method applies HTML encoding to the specified string, <cHTML>.

member.name: M:VO.IServer._MapPath
member.summary: Map the specified relative or virtual path to the corresponding physical directory on the server.
member.param: The alias name of the path.
member.returns: The full specified path including drive letter, if successful; otherwise, NULL_STRING.
member.remarks: The _MapPath() method maps the specified relative or virtual path, <cPath>, to the corresponding physical directory on the server. If <cPath> starts with either a forward (/) or backward (\) slash, this method returns a path as if <cPath> is a full virtual path. If <cPath> does not start with a slash, _MapPath() returns a path relative to the directory of the .ASP file being processed.
member.example:
The following call to method _MapPath(),
CLASS ASPComponent INHERIT IScriptingContext METHOD HTTPResponse CLASS ASPComponent LOCAL cPath AS STRING ... cPath := SELF:Server:_MapPath("/cgi-bin") ...
produces the output (cPath): c:\inetsrv\scripts However, the call to cPath := SELF:Server:_MapPath("test") produces the output (cPath): c:\inetsrv\wwwroot\vosample\test

member.name: M:VO.IServer._URLEncode
member.summary: Apply URL encoding to a specified string.
member.param: The URL string to be encoded.
member.returns: The encoded URL text as STRING, if successful; otherwise, NULL_STRING.
member.remarks: This method applies URL encoding to the specified string, <cURL>.
member.example:
The following call to method _URLEncode(),
CLASS ASPComponent INHERIT IScriptingContext METHOD HTTPResponse CLASS ASPComponent LOCAL cEncode AS STRING ... cEncode := SELF:Server:_URLEncode( ; "X#") ...
produces the output (cEncode): Visual+Objects

member.name: M:VO.IWriteCookie.#ctor

An IServer object instance.
member.remarks: An IWriteCookie object instance can be created by the IResponse:GetCookies() method because it is directly associated with an HTTP request. Therefore, you do not have to create this object yourself. Rather, use it for an ASP Component application via the IScriptingContext:Response:GetCookies() method.

member.name: M:VO.IWriteCookie.PutDomain
member.summary: Set the Domain attribute of a cookie object.
member.param: New domain value as STRING.
member.returns: TRUE if successful; otherwise, FALSE.
member.remarks: This method sets the new value for the Domain attribute of the IWriteCookie object. This attribute determines whether the cookie is sent only to requests to this domain.

member.name: M:VO.IWriteCookie.PutExpires
member.summary: Set the current value of the Expires property of a cookie object.
member.param: New expires value as DATE.
member.returns: TRUE if successful; otherwise, FALSE.
member.remarks: This method sets the new value for the Expires property of the IWriteCookie object. This property specifies the date at which a cookie expires.

member.name: M:VO.IWriteCookie.PutItem
member.summary: Add a specified cookie to a write-only cookie collection.
member.param: Name of the item to add to the cookie as STRING.
Value of the item to add to the cookie as STRING.
Array with item values to add to the cookie. <cName> is treated as the key name and the cookie as a dictionary cookie.
member.returns: TRUE if successful; otherwise, FALSE.
member.remarks: This method adds a new item to the IWriteCookie object. If the second argument is a STRING, then the cookie is treated as a simple cookie and <cValue> is the cookie's value. Otherwise, the cookie is treated as a dictionary cookie and <aValues> contains the values for the cookie's key, <cName>.

member.name: M:VO.IWriteCookie.PutPath
member.summary: Set the Path attribute of a cookie object.
member.param: New Path value as STRING.
member.returns: TRUE if successful; otherwise, FALSE.
member.remarks: This method sets the new value for the Path attribute of the IWriteCookie object. This attribute determines whether the cookie is sent only to requests to this path. If this attribute is not set, the application path is used.

member.name: M:VO.IWriteCookie.PutSecure

member.param: Logical value with new Secure attribute.
member.returns: TRUE if successful; otherwise, FALSE.

member.name: M:VO.ListBox.AddItem(XSharp.__Usual,XSharp.__Usual,XSharp.__Usual)
member.summary: Add a new item to a list box at a specified position.
member.param: The item to be inserted.
The position in the list box at which to insert the new item. Specify one of the values listed below.
The value associated with the specified item. The default is <cItem>.
member.returns: If the item was added, its position in the list box is returned (a value of 1 refers to the first position in the list box). If the item could not be added, 0 is returned.
member.remarks: Value Position 0 In an unsorted list box, adds the new item at the end of the list; if sorted, inserts the new item at a position determined by the list box. This is the default. 1 The first position in the list box. n The nth position in the list box.

member.name: M:VO.ListBox.ChangeSelected(XSharp.__Usual,XSharp.__Usual)
member.summary: Change a range of items in a multiple selection list box to a specified selection.
member.param: The Range object representing the selected items.
The state of the selected items. If not specified, the default is TRUE.
member.returns: TRUE if successful; otherwise, FALSE.
member.remarks: This method is intended for use with a multiple selection list box (i.e., a list box created using the LBOXMULTIPLESEL style).

member.name: M:VO.ListBox.ClearSelection
member.summary: Clear a multiple selection list box of all selections.
member.returns: TRUE if successful; otherwise, FALSE.
member.remarks: This method is intended for use with a multiple selection list box (i.e., a list box created using the LBOXMULTIPLESEL style).

member.name: M:VO.ListBox.DeleteItem(XSharp.__Usual)

member.param: The number of the item to be deleted. Specify one of values listed below
member.returns: TRUE if successful; otherwise, FALSE.

member.name: M:VO.ListBox.DeselectItem(XSharp.__Usual)
member.summary: Turn off the selection of a specified item in a list box.
member.param: The item number to be deselected. Zero (0) represents the current item.
member.returns: TRUE if successful; otherwise, FALSE.

member.name: M:VO.ListBox.Destroy

member.remarks: This method can be used when a ListBox object is no longer needed. ListBox:Destroy() de-instantiates the ListBox object and allows you to close and free any resources that were opened or created by the object, without waiting for the garbage collector.

member.name: M:VO.ListBox.FillUsing(XSharp.__Usual,XSharp.__Usual,XSharp.__Usual)
member.summary: Specify the set of values to be displayed in the list box, using an array or a data server. These values act as a constraint on the values that may be entered in the list box, and optionally as a translation between program values and display values.
member.param:
An array containing the values to be placed in the list box. A two-dimensional array may be used to define the values to be returned to the program when a list item is selected, separately from the text strings shown in the list; this 'other' value is what is returned in the ListBox:Value property, and what is stored in the database if the control is associated with a database field.
Thus, the array may be specified in one of two formats:
One-dimensional array containing the list of values.

Array of two-element arrays, each containing the string to display in the list and the corresponding value returned to the program.
Note that the two dimensional array has the same structure as that returned by DBServer:GetLookupTable(), and the one-dimensional array matches that returned by DBServer:GetArray(). or The data server that is to be used to provide the set of values.
The symbolic name of the field that is to be used for the display values. If not specified, the values of the first field are used.
The symbolic name of the field that is to be used for the values that are returned to the program. If not specified, the values of the first field are used.
member.remarks: A list box shows the set of valid values for a field. Depending on what type of list box is used, the set of values may act as a constraint on the values that may be retrieved or only as a suggestion. Two sets of values may be specified, allowing for translation of values between the displayed, "human-readable" representation and the internal, programmatic value. The FillUsing() method provides a way of specifying the values to be included in the list all at once, instead of constructing the list item by item with the AddItem() method. The list box control may be associated with a database field, just like any other control. Do not confuse this primary field linkage with the possibility of linking the list box to a secondary server used for populating the list.

member.name: M:VO.ListBox.FirstSelected
member.summary: Returns the position of the first item selected in a multiple selection list box, or 0 if no item is selected.
member.remarks: ListBox:FirstSelected() positions an imaginary cursor on the first item of the selection. This method is intended for use with a multiple selection list box (i.e., a list box created using the LBOXMULTIPLESEL style).

member.name: M:VO.ListBox.GetItemValue(XSharp.__Usual)
member.summary: Retrieve the value of a specified list box item.
member.param: The number of the desired item. Specify one of the values listed below:
member.returns: The value associated with the specified item.
member.remarks: Value Position 0 The currently selected item. 1 The first item. n The nth item.

example.code: METHOD ListBoxClick(oControlEvent) CLASS EmailWindow LOCAL oControl := oControlEvent:Control AS Control SUPER:ListBoxClick(oControlEvent) IF IsInstanceOf(oControl, #ListBox) SELF:DialClient(oControl:GetItemValue(0)) ENDIF RETURN NIL

member.summary: Fill a list box with the names of all files that match the specified path or file name.

item.description: Includes archived files.

member.name: M:VO.ListView.AddItem(XSharp.__Usual)
member.summary: Add a new ListViewItem object as the last item in the list view.
member.param: The ListViewItem object to add to the list view.
member.returns: TRUE if the item was added successfully; otherwise, FALSE.
member.example:
The example below shows how to populate a ListView control. Note that it is also storing the record number with each item also for later retrieval when any given item is selected:
LOCAL cCoachName AS string LOCAL oItem AS ListViewItem DO WHILE !SELF:oCoachesServer:eof cCoachName := Trim( SELF:oCoachesServer:FIELDGET( #LastName ) ) ; + ", " + ; Trim( SELF:oCoachesServer:FIELDGET( #FirstName ) ) + " " + ; SELF:oCoachesServer:FIELDGET( #MiddleInit ) oItem:SetText( SELF:oCoachesServer:FIELDGET( #Season ), #cSeason ) oItem:SetValue( SELF:oCoachesServer:RecNo, #cCoachName ) oItem:SetText( CoachName, #cCoachName ) oItem:SetText( SELF:oCoachesServer:FIELDGET( #Gender ), #cGender ) oItem:SetText( SELF:oCoachesServer:FIELDGET( #ClubCode ), #cClubCode ) oItem:SetText( SELF:oCoachesServer:FIELDGET( #TeamNr ), #cTeamNr ) oItem:SetText( SELF:oCoachesServer:FIELDGET( #HomePhone ), #cHomePhone ) oItem:SetText( SELF:oCoachesServer:FIELDGET( #WorkPhone ), #cWorkPhone )
SELF:oDClvCoaches:AddItem( oItem ) SELF:oCoachesServer:skip() ENDDO

member.name: M:VO.ListView.EnableSort(XSharp.__Usual)
member.summary: Register a user-defined method to use for sorting items in the list view.
member.param: The symbolic name of the user-defined method that will be used to sort items in the list view. When called, this method receives two ListViewItem objects as arguments. The method should determine which of the two list view items should come first in the list view. If the first item precedes the second, this method should return -1; if the second item precedes the first, this method should return 1; if the items are equivalent, this method should return 0.
member.returns: The symbolic name of the user-defined method to perform the sort.

member.name: M:VO.ListView.GetNextItem(XSharp.__Usual,XSharp.__Usual,XSharp.__Usual,XSharp.__Usual,XSharp.__Usual,XSharp.__Usual)
member.summary: Retrieve the next list view item that possesses all of the specified properties.
member.param: One of the following constants describing the physical relationship to the specified item. See table below for possible values
A value of TRUE indicates that the list view item's image should be disabled. If omitted, the default is FALSE.
A value of TRUE indicates that the list view item should be a drag and drop target. If omitted, the default is FALSE.
A value of TRUE indicates that the list view item should be focused. If omitted, the default is FALSE.
A value of TRUE indicates that the list view item should be selected. If omitted, the default is FALSE.
Index of the item with which to begin searching. If omitted, searching starts from the beginning.
member.returns: The list view item returned as a result of the search.

item.description: Searches for an item that is above the specified item
Searches for an item that is below the specified item
Searches for a subsequent item by index (the default value)
Searches for an item to the left of the specified item
Searches for an item to the right of the specified item

member.example:
The example below shows how to traverse all items in a ListView for further processing. Note that the GetNextItem() method's last parameter is zero-based:
LOCAL oLVI AS ListViewItem nCount := SELF:oDClvPlayers:ItemCount FOR x := 1 UPTO nCount oLVI := SELF:oDClvPlayers:GetNextItem( LV_GNIBYITEM,,,,,x-1 ) cID := AllTrim( oLVI:GetText( #cPlayerID ) ) nRecNo := oLVI:GetValue( #cPlayerID ) NEXT x

member.name: M:VO.ListView.Seek(XSharp.__Usual,XSharp.__Usual,XSharp.__Usual,XSharp.__Usual,XSharp.__Usual)
member.summary: Search the list view for a particular list view item.
member.param: The value to seek. <kSeekType> must be LV_SEEKVALUE.
The string to seek. <kSeekType> must be LV_SEEKTEXT.
The point in the client area of the list view at which the seek begins. The nearest list view item to this point in the direction specified by <kSeekType> will be returned.

A constant that specifies what type of seek to perform. LV_SEEKVALUE causes a seek on a usual value. LV_SEEKTEXT causes a seek on a text string. If the seek is on a Point object, this argument can be LV_SEEKUP or LV_SEEKDOWN to specify a search in the respective directions. In this case, if the argument is omitted, LV_SEEKDOWN is assumed.
The index of the list view item at which to begin the search. If omitted, the seek begins at the first item.
A value of TRUE continues the search at the first list view item if no match is found. If omitted, the default is FALSE, which disables wrapping.
A value of TRUE produces a match if the list view item label begins with <cText>. If omitted, the default is FALSE, which disables partial seeking.
member.returns: The list view item returned as a result of the seek.

member.name: M:VO.ListView.SetColumnFormat(XSharp.__Usual,XSharp.__Usual,XSharp.__Usual)
member.summary: Set the desired extended style for a list view.
member.param: The column index number.

Flags that can be set to create the required style. More than one style can be used by combining them with _Or()
Available styles are -
HDF_CENTER Allign the column to the center.
HDF_LEFT Allign the column to the left. This is the default.
HDF_RIGHT Allign the column to the right.
HDF_BITMAP Add a bitmap to the left of the column.
HDF_BITMAP_ON_RIGHT Add a bitmap to the right of the column.
HDF_SORTDOWN down arrow in header - For visual themes only
HDF_SORTUP up arrow in header - For visual themes only
the number of the image in the image list to display in the column header. The default is no image.
member.returns: TRUE, if the style was enabled; otherwise, FALSE.

member.name: M:VO.LogFile.DebugMsg(System.String)
member.summary: Add a message to the log file.
member.param: String containing the message.
member.remarks: This method adds a message to the log file.

member.name: M:VO.LogFile.DumpError(XSharp.__Usual)
member.summary: Add the runtime error description to the log file.
member.param: Error object instance.
member.remarks: This method adds the error description to the log file.
member.example:
The following common framework for CGI applications uses the LogFile class to log error messages and application progress information:
CLASS MyFilter INHERIT LogFile CLASS StdHTTPContext INHERIT HTTPCGIContext FUNCTION Start LOCAL oCGI AS StdHTTPContext LOCAL cHtml AS STRING LOCAL oOldError AS USUAL LOCAL oError AS USUAL LOCAL oLogFile AS LogFile oLogFile := LogFile{} #IFDEF __DEBUG__ oCGI:DebugMsg("CGI application started") #ENDIF oCGI := StdHTTPContext{} oOldError := ErrorBlock( {|oErr|__MyError(oErr)} ) BEGIN SEQUENCE cHtml := oCGI:HTTPResponse() IF SLen(cHtml) > 0 // // Default behavior, return a HTML // oCGI:Write(cHtml) ENDIF RECOVER USING oError cHtml := oCGI:HTTPErrorMessage(oError) oCGI:Write(cHtml) oLogFile:DumpError(oError) END SEQUENCE ErrorBlock( oOldError ) oCGI:Close() #IFDEF __DEBUG__ oCGI:DebugMsg("CGI application finished") #ENDIF RETURN STATIC FUNC __MyError (oError) LOCAL cRepl AS STRING cRepl := "Module " + ProcName(1) cRepl += ", line " + NTrim(ProcLine(1)) IF SLen(oError:Description) > 0 oError:Description += "(" + cRepl + ")" ELSE oError:Description := cRepl ENDIF BREAK(oError)

member.name: M:VO.LogFile.#ctor(XSharp.__Usual,XSharp.__Usual,XSharp.__Usual)
member.summary: Construct a LogFile object instance.
member.param: Log file name. If not specified, the log file name is identical to the application name. The extension is .LOG.

Specifies whether the log file should be created within the directory specified as LogFileDirectory by Windows (TRUE), or if the log file should be created within the application's directory (FALSE). The default is FALSE.

Flag determining whether log messages should be appended to the end of an existing log file (TRUE), or if any existing log file should be overwritten by log messages of that object (FALSE). The default is TRUE.

One of the following:

member.name: M:VO.Menu.CheckItem(XSharp.__Usual)
member.summary: Place a check mark to the left of a specified menu item.
member.param: The ID of the menu command.
member.returns: MF_CHECKED if checked, MF_UNCHECKED if unchecked
member.remarks: Placing a check mark next to a menu item indicates its state. The state of such a command is usually indicated to the user by the check mark, which does or does not appear depending on whether the command is on or off. You can later use the Menu:UncheckItem() method to remove the check mark. You can also use this method to check a menu item on a submenu.

member.name: M:VO.Menu.Destroy
member.summary: Provide a method to de-instantiate a Menu object.
member.remarks: This method can be used when a Menu object is no longer needed. Menu:Destroy() de-instantiates the Menu object and allows you to close and free any resources that were opened or created by the object, without waiting for the garbage collector.

member.name: M:VO.Menu.DisableItem(XSharp.__Usual)
member.summary: Disable a specified menu item (until a subsequent call to Menu:EnableItem()).
member.param: The ID of the menu item to be disabled.
member.returns: A LONG indicating the previous state of the item. If the item does not exist the return value is -1.
member.remarks: Disabled menu items are not active and, therefore, they do not send events to their owner windows. Note that under Windows, a disabled menu command is dimmed. You can also use this method to disable a menu item on a submenu.

member.name: M:VO.Menu.EnableItem(XSharp.__Usual)
member.summary: Enable a specified menu item that was previously disabled.
member.param: The ID of the menu item to be enabled.
member.returns: A LONG indicating the previous state of the item. If the item does not exist the return value is -1.
member.remarks: Enabling a menu item allows it to generate events and to send the events to its owner window when the user manipulates the menu command. The dimming of disabled menu item is removed, and the menu item is restored to its normal appearance. By default, menu item are enabled until disabled, so there is no need to call this EnableItem() method unless DisableItem() was previously called. You can also use this method to enable a menu item on a submenu of a menu.

member.name: M:VO.MultiMediaContainer.Dispatch(XSharp.__Usual)
member.summary: Provide the prototype dispatcher for events within the system when the control has focus, routing various events to their appropriate event handlers. Important! This is a callback method used by X#.
member.param: The event to be handled.
member.returns: A numeric value representing the event handler that handled the event.
member.remarks: MultiMediaContainer:Dispatch() serves as an internal callback method, dispatching events to various event handlers. It should never be necessary to call this method directly. Instead you should write your own Dispatch() method for derived classes, if you want to handle additional events. Usually the derived class Dispatch() method should call SUPER:Dispatch() to support the inherited event handling.

member.name: M:VO.MultiMediaContainer.#ctor(XSharp.__Usual,XSharp.__Usual,XSharp.__Usual,XSharp.__Usual)

The resource ID of the control.
member.remarks: This method instantiates a MultiMediaContainer object. Depending on the file assigned to it, the MultiMediaContainer object tries to display the multimedia data. In the case of video or audio data, it creates an MCI child window. For images, X# image support attempts to display the image in the control's client area.

member.name: M:VO.MultiMediaContainer.MCISendMessage(XSharp.__Usual,XSharp.__Usual,XSharp.__Usual)
member.summary: Send an MCIWNDM_XXX message to the contained MCI window.
member.param: The message ID.
The first SendMessage parameter as DWORD. The default is 0.
The second SendMessage parameter as LONG. The default is 0.
member.returns: The result value (as LONG).
member.remarks: If the associated file contains video or audio information (for example, an .AVI or .WAV file), the MultiMediaContainer class creates an MCI window. Using the MCISendMessage() method, you can send any of the MCIWNDM_XXX messages documented in the Win32 SDK help to this window. Using these messages, you can programmatically change the look and behavior of the window, play the multimedia data, etc. Consult your Microsoft Win32 Software Development Kit documentation for detailed information about MCIWNDM_XXX messages and commands.
member.example:
This code snippet starts the playback of a video or audio file: oDCMM:MCISendMessage(MCIWNDM_PLAYFROM) This code snippet advances the data step by step: oDCMM:MCISendMessage(MCI_STEP, 0, 1) This code snippet removes the toolbar from the window:
oDCMM:MCISendMessage(MCIWNDM_CHANGESTYLES, MCIWNDF_NOPLAYBAR, ; MCIWNDF_NOPLAYBAR)

member.name: M:VO.OLEAutoObjectFromFile.Destroy
member.summary: Provide a method to de-instantiate an OLE automation server.
member.remarks: OLEAutoObjectFromFile:Destroy() shuts down an OLE automation session and releases all the data associated with it. This method is called automatically by OLEAutoObject:Axit(), which is triggered by the garbage collector, but you can also call OLEAutoObjectFromFile:Destroy() directly.

member.name: M:VO.OLEAutoObjectFromFile.#ctor
member.summary: Create an OLE automation server from a file.
member.param: The name of file from which to create the OLE automation server.
The language ID for automation servers that support multiple language. The default value is zero.
member.remarks: Init() initializes an OLEAutoObjectFromFile and tries to link it to the automation server that is registered for the file <cFName>. OLE automation servers might support different languages for the names of methods, properties, and variables. The desired language is specified through the <nLangID> argument. The value zero tells the server to use its default language. For details about the supported languages, their identifiers, and the default language, refer to the documentation for your specific automation server. Important! In order for this class to work the automation server must implement the IPersistFile interface — most automation servers do not.

member.name: M:VO.OLEAutoObject.Destroy
member.summary: Provide a method to de-instantiate an OLE automation server.
member.remarks: OLEAutoObject:Destroy() shuts down an OLE automation session and releases all the data associated with it. This method is called automatically by OLEAutoObject:Axit(), which is triggered by the garbage collector, but you can also call OLEAutoObject:Destroy() directly, as illustrated in the example below.

member.name: M:VO.OLEAutoObject.#ctor
member.summary: Construct an OLE automation server.
member.param: A string, IDispatch object, Interface Pointer or OleAutoObject specifying the automation server.
The language ID for automation servers that support multiple language. The default value is zero.
Reserved. The default value is FALSE.
Should X# return a reference to an already running server (TRUE) or create a new instance of the server (FALSE). The default value is FALSE.
member.remarks: Init() initializes an OLEAutoObject and tries to link it to the specified automation server. Usually, you will specify the automation server (OLE defined PROGID) using its name as a string (i.e., <cServer>). You can, however, specify it as an object of the IDispatch class (i.e., <oIDispatch>). This is required to handle interface hierarchies in OLE automation. A method, property, or variable might return an OLE interface, that in turn represents an automation object with its own methods, properties, and variables. The invoke logic of the automation class will automatically turn a returned OLE automation interface in a new OLEAutoObject object, by first creating an IDispatch object, then creating a new OLEAutoObject object and passing the IDispatch object to its Init() method. Alternate parameters are an IDispatch pointer or an OleAutoObject. IDispatch Pointers are handled just like IDispatch objects. When you pass in an OleAutoObject X# will create a second OleAutoObject that points to the same COM Interface. X# will make sure that the reference counting is adjusted to reflect the fact that TWO VO Objects are passing to the same OLE Object. The invoke logic in generated subclasses of OLEAutoObject handles return OLE automation interfaces in this manner, so that normally there is no need for the user to pass IDispatch objects to OLEAutoObject:Init(). OLE automation servers might support different languages for the names of methods, properties, and variables. The desired language is specified through the <nLangID> argument. The value zero tells the server to use its default language. For details about the supported languages, their identifiers, and the default language, refer to the documentation for your specific automation server. The <lNoFuncArray> parameter has to be considered reserved. It is only used by generated subclasses of OLEAutoObject to prevent the Init() method from creating OLEAutoObject:aFuncDesc (an array containing descriptions for all methods, properties, and variables of the automation server). Because this array is not needed by generated subclasses of OLEAutoObject, they call the Init() method using a value of TRUE for this argument. The default value, and the value that is normally used, is FALSE. The <fROTCheck> parameter determines if X# will create a new instance of the server or if it will try to see if the server is already running. The default behavior is to create a new server (fROTCheck = FALSE). When you specify a TRUE for this parameter, X#will inspect the OLE Running Objects Table and try to attach to an already running server by calling the GetActiveObject() API function. When that fails, X# will create a new server
member.example:
This example creates a Word Application automation server:
FUNCTION Start() LOCAL oApp AS OBJECT LOCAL oDocs AS OBJECT LOCAL oDoc AS OBJECT ? "Starting Word" oApp := OleAutoObject{"Word.Application"} oApp:Visible := TRUE oDocs := oApp:Documents ? "Loading Document" oDoc := oDocs:Open("C:\Cavo28\whatsnew.rtf") ? "Printing Document" oApp:PrintOut(NamedArg{#Background, TRUE}, ; NamedArg{#PrintToFile, TRUE}, ; NamedArg{#OutputFileName, "C:\TEST.TXT"}) DO WHILE oApp:BackgroundPrintingStatus != 0 ? "." DoEvents() ENDDO ? "Closing WORD" oDoc:Close(FALSE) oApp:Quit() wait "Done" RETURN NIL

member.name: M:VO.OleBinary.AsString
member.summary: Returns the string representation of the OleBinary Object When the type is known, it can be a text such as ‘Word Document’ or ‘Bitmap’. Otherwise it is a hex dump from the contents

member.name: M:VO.OleBinary.#ctor
member.summary: Construct a NamedArg object.
member.param: This can be a string. SafeArray or another OleBinary object.If you pass in a SafeArray, then the class creates a clone of the SafeArray. You remain the owner of the original SafeArray. If you pass in an OleBinary then it clones that object.

member.name: M:VO.OLEControl.CreateEmbedding
member.summary: Create an OLE control from a program ID.
member.param: The OLE control's program ID.
The license key for the OLE control's program.
member.returns: TRUE if successful; otherwise, FALSE.
member.remarks: Each object provided by an OLE server is uniquely identified by its program ID. These program IDs are stored in the system Registry as described in the OLE server's documentation. OLEControl:CreateEmbedding() creates an embedded OLE control from its program ID and loads it into an OLEControl container.
member.example:
The following code responds to a button click by creating an object with the program ID Word.Document.6 within an already existing OLEControl container sitting on a data window:
METHOD PushButton1() CLASS dw oDCOLEControl1:CreateEmbedding("Word.Document.6")

member.name: M:VO.OLEControl.CreateFromAppDocStorage
member.summary: Create an OLEControl from an Application Doc File storage.
member.param: The OLEAppDocStorage object containing the object.
member.returns: TRUE if successful; otherwise, FALSE.
member.remarks: All OLE controls inserted into a form inside the Window Editor are saved inside a special file called the Application Doc File. When the OLE control is recreated at runtime, the persistent information, including the OLEAutoObject, is loaded from the Application Doc File using OLEControl:CreateFromAppDocStorage().

member.name: M:VO.OLEControl.Destroy
member.summary: Provide a method to de-instantiate an OLEControl object.
member.param: The event to be handled.
member.remarks: This method can be used when an OLEControl object is no longer needed. OLEControl:Destroy() de-instantiates the OLEControl object and allows you to close and free any resources that were opened or created by the object, without waiting for the garbage collector. The associated OLE control is automatically closed and the OLE control's server is shut down, unless it is serving other clients.

member.name: M:VO.OLEControl.Dispatch
member.summary: Provide the prototype dispatcher for events within the system when the control has focus; routing various events to their appropriate event handlers.
member.param: The event to be handled.
member.returns: TRUE if the event was handled; otherwise, FALSE.
member.remarks: OLEControl:Dispatch() serves as an internal callback, dispatching events to various event handlers. It should never be necessary to call this method directly. Instead, you can write your own Dispatch() method for derived classes if you want to handle additional events. Usually the derived class Dispatch() should call SUPER:Dispatch() to support the inherited event handling.

member.name: M:VO.OLEControl.InitAutoObject
member.summary: Initialize the OLEAutoObject.
member.returns: SELF
member.remarks: The OLEAutoObject must be initialized after the OLE control is created. OLEControl:CreateFromAppDocStorage() does this automatically. If you use one of the other Create methods, however, make sure to initialize the OLEAutoObject properly using OLEControl:InitAutoObject().

member.name: M:VO.OLEControl.No
member.summary: Provide a general error interception that is automatically called whenever a reference is made to a non-existent method. Important! NoMethod() should not be called directly; it is called by the system for handling invalid references.

member.name: M:VO.OLEDataWindow.DeactivateAllOLEObjects(XSharp.__Usual)
member.summary:
Note The functionality in this method has now been incorporated into the Window Class.
Deactivate all currently active OLE objects.
member.remarks: The DeactivateAllOLEObjects() method deactivates any currently (in-place) active OLE objects. The method is called automatically whenever the data window itself is deactivated.

member.name: M:VO.OLEDataWindow.DeActivate(XSharp.__Usual)
member.summary:
Note The functionality in this method has now been incorporated into the Window Class.
Provide a method that is invoked when the OLE data window is deactivated. Important! Deactivate() is a callback method used by X#. Normally, it should not be called in your application code.
member.param: An empty event required to maintain the protocol that all event handlers have exactly one event as their argument.
member.remarks: This event handler is normally invoked when another application or window becomes activated. By default, all OLE objects on the OLEDataWindow will be deactivated. If Window:MouseTrapOn() is left on, MouseEvent events cannot be directed to other applications or windows.

member.name: M:VO.OLEDataWindow.#ctor(XSharp.__Usual,XSharp.__Usual,XSharp.__Usual)
member.summary:
Note The functionality in this method has now been incorporated into the Window Class.
Construct an OLE data window.
member.param:
The window that owns the OLE data window. The following window types can be owners: App, ShellWindow, TopAppWindow, ChildAppWindow, DialogWindow, DataDialog, or another DataWindow.
The behavior of the OLE data window is determined by the type of its owner.
The ID of the resource that defines the layout of the OLE data window. If not specified, the OLE data window automatically lays itself out when attached to a data server.

The resource ID that specifies the location and size of the sub-data window. Specifying this argument creates the new OLE data window as a sub-data window on its owner data window (only data window owners can have sub-data windows). It should refer to a control defined in the resource entity of the owner data window.
If <nResourceID> is omitted or if <oOwner> is not a data window, the data window is created as a modal DialogWindow.
member.remarks: An OLE data window is an enhanced data window which can be used to host OLE objects. It provides the additional functionality needed for OLE objects. For more details, please see the specific methods for the OLEDataWindow class.

member.name: M:VO.OLEDataWindow.MouseButtonDown(XSharp.__Usual)
member.summary:
Note The functionality in this method has now been incorporated into the Window Class.
Provide an event handler that is invoked when the mouse pointer is positioned over the window and a mouse button is clicked. Important! This is a callback method used by X#. Normally, it should not be called in your application code.
member.param: The MouseEvent object that contains information about the state of the mouse when the button was clicked.
member.remarks: By default, this method will deactivate all OLE object controls on the window before processing the MouseEvent. Use the Window:MouseTrapOn() method to force MouseEvents generated outside the canvas area to be directed to this window.

member.name: M:VO.OLEDataWindow.Notify(XSharp.__Usual,XSharp.__Usual)
member.summary:
Note The functionality in this method has now been incorporated into the DataWindow Class.
Provide an event handler that reflects events that have occurred in the server connected to an OLE data window. Important! Notify() is automatically called by the server, and should normally not be called by application code.
member.param: Identifies the event, specified as one of the constants listed below.
Used only with some notification types, as described above.
member.returns: SELF, except if NOTIFYINTENTTOMOVE is specified for <kNotifyName>. In this case, the return value is TRUE if successful; otherwise, FALSE.
member.remarks:
Constant Meaning NOTIFYAPPEND A blank record has been appended to the server; the server is still positioned on this new record, and its values have not been finalized. NOTIFYCLEARRELATION Not sent to a data window. NOTIFYCLOSE The server intends to close itself. NOTIFYCOMPLETION The server has completed some large operation that did not involve repositioning of the server or change to the data (such as reindexing). This gives the window a chance to update visual indication to the user that some operation has been completed. <uDescription> is the name of the method that was just completed, as a symbol. NOTIFYDELETE The current record has been deleted, and the server is now positioned according to its rules for how a deletion is handled. The window should refresh its display accordingly. NOTIFYFIELDCHANGE A field has changed. <uDescription> is the field name as a symbol. Note that the window might not contain a control with the indicated name. The server knows only that it has a field of that name and that it changed, and it notifies all its clients in case they are interested. NOTIFYFILECHANGE The server has executed some method that perform many changes to the data; all the window's knowledge about the server and its data is potentially obsolete, and it should refresh all information from the server and all calculations that depend on the data or its position. NOTIFYGOBOTTOM The server has moved to its last record. Many clients treat this merely as a record change, but windows in browse view can treat a positioning-to-the-end as a special case. NOTIFYGOTOP The server has moved to its first record. Many clients treat this merely as a record change, but windows in browse view can treat a positioning-to-the-top as a special case. NOTIFYINTENTTOMOVE The server intends to make a move. (Note that the move may have been initiated by another client.)The window should make sure that all its data is saved, if necessary, before the movement is done. The standard implementation checks validation status. If the window contains data that is invalid, the user has a choice of correcting the errors or discarding the data. NOTIFYRECORDCHANGE The record position of the server has changed. All clients are notified after any movement, so they can refresh their displays from the server. <uDescription> might indicate the length of the move (the number of records). The window can use this information for display optimization but cannot rely on its availability. NOTIFYRELATIONCHANGE Not sent to data windows (relation changes among servers are transmitted to clients as file changes). This Notify() method is at the heart of the automatic notification among linked browsers and servers, allowing any window to make a change to a field value or initiate a movement and also ensuring that all client windows reflect the change. Any class that is registered as a client of a server must respond intelligently to the Notify message. In addition to the functionality provided by the DataWindow base class, the implementation for the OLEDataWindow class also deactivates any activated OLE objects before doing database operations, such as SKIPs. As always with defined constants, you should never rely on the actual values of the constants -- they will not necessarily stay the same. However, the constants do maintain their order: Constant Value Level NOTIFYFIELDCHANGE Lowest NOTIFYCLOSE ... NOTIFYCOMPLETION ... NOTIFYINTENTTOMOVE ... NOTIFYRECORDCHANGE ... NOTIFYGOBOTTOM ... NOTIFYGOTOP ... NOTIFYDELETE ... NOTIFYAPPEND ... NOTIFYFILECHANGE ... NOTIFYRELATIONCHANGE ... NOTIFYCLEARRELATION Highest Thus, you can reliably write:
IF kNotifyName > NOTIFYINTENTTOMOVE; .AND. kNotifyName < NOTIFYFILECHANGE ... // Only record level moves ENDIF

member.name: M:VO.OLEDataWindow.UpdateActiveObject
member.summary:
Note The functionality in this method has now been incorporated into the DataWindow Class.
Update the toolbars of any in-place active OLE objects.
member.remarks: OLEDataWindow:UpdateActiveObject() calls the UpdateTools() method of any currently activated OLE object that the OLE data window contains. It first determines which OLE object control is in-place active, and then replaces the X# container application's toolbars with the OLE server's toolbars. In response to a resizing of the container application, this method causes the OLE object server to rearrange its toolbars.

member.name: M:VO.OLEDataWindow.ViewAs(XSharp.__Usual)
member.summary:
Note The functionality in this method has now been incorporated into the DataWindow Class.
Specify the view mode of the OLE data window as either browse view or form view.
member.param:
Specifies which view mode is to be used. Use one of these symbols:
Symbol Description
#BrowseView Several records are displayed at the same time, as rows in a spreadsheet-like table with each field corresponding to a column.
#FormView A single record is viewed at a time, with its fields displayed in individual controls.
member.remarks: When a window is switched to a new view mode, a layout is automatically generated if one had not been defined previously. Because it takes an argument, OLEDataWindow:ViewAs() is rarely connected directly with a push button or menu command; instead, the OLEDataWindow:ViewForm() and OLEDataWindow:ViewTable() methods (inherited from DataWindow) are used. In addition to the functionality provided by the DataWindow base class, the implementation for the OLEDataWindow class also deactivates any activated OLE objects before changing the view.

member.name: M:VO.OleDateTime.AsReal8
member.summary: Returns the DateTime value as Real8 (the format that is used in COM).

member.name: M:VO.OleDateTime.AsString
member.summary: Returns the dateTime value as a String.

member.name: M:VO.OleDateTime.#ctor
member.summary: Construct an OleDateTime object.
member.param: This can be passed as a number or as a VO date.
member.remarks: The OleDateTime class can be initialized in two ways: - With a VO Date, in which case the time portion is set to 00:00:00.00 - With a number, in which case the Integer is taken as the number of days from December 30th 1899 to make the date. The fraction is then taken as a fraction of a day to make the time portion of the object.

member.name: M:VO.OLEDBStorage.#ctor
member.summary: Construct an OLEDBStorage object.
member.param: A pointer to the root storage.
A string representing the substorage name.
member.remarks: OLEDBStorage objects are usually a result of a FieldGet() call. It should never be necessary to call this method directly.

member.name: M:VO.OleDragEvent.#ctor(XSharp.__Usual)
member.summary: Construct an OLEDragEvent.
member.param: A pointer to a DRAGINFO structure.

member.name: M:VO.OLEObject.Activate
member.summary: Activate the OLE object.
member.returns: TRUE if successful; otherwise, FALSE.
member.remarks: The method puts the associated OLE object into the active state, which usually allows the user to edit the object.
member.example:
The following code shows a push button's click event handler, which activates an OLEObject located on the same data window:
METHOD PushButton1() CLASS dw oDCOLEObject1:Activate("Word.Document.6")

member.name: M:VO.OLEObject.AddVerbMenu
member.summary: Insert the OLE object's verb menu into an existing menu.
member.param: The handle of the existing menu.
The position at which the menu should be inserted.
member.returns: TRUE if successful; otherwise, FALSE.
member.remarks: A OLE object usually supports several actions (called verbs) which a user can perform on the object. An AVI object, for example, can support a Play and an Edit verb. The object's verbs can be invoked via its verb menu, which is added using OLEObject:AddVerbMenu() into an existing menu and is fully managed by the object.
member.example:
The following code inserts the verb menu at position two of the pop-up menu with ID one of the container application. Note that the system menu of an MDI child window counts as separate pop-up menu, in case the MDI child window is maximized:
LOCAL hObjMenu AS PTR IF oParent:IsZoomed() hObjMenu := oParent:Menu:GetSubMenu(2) ELSE hObjMenu := oParent:Menu:GetSubMenu(1) ENDIF SELF:AddVerbMenu(hObjMenu, 2)

member.name: M:VO.OLEObject.CreateEmbeddingFromFile
member.summary: Create an OLE object from a file.
member.param: The file containing the object.
member.returns: TRUE if successful; otherwise, FALSE.
member.remarks: If an OLE object is given as a file (such as a saved document). you use OLEObject:CreateEmbeddingFromFile() to create an embedded OLE object and load it into its OLEObject container.
member.example:
The following code responds to a button click by creating an object from the file \WINWORD\SAMPLE.DOC:
METHOD PushButton1() CLASS dw oDCOLEObject1:CreateEmbeddingFromFile("\WINWORD\SAMPLE.DOC")

member.name: M:VO.OLEObject.CreateEmbedding
member.summary: Create an OLE object from a program ID.
member.param: The OLE object's program ID.
member.returns: TRUE if successful; otherwise, FALSE.
member.remarks: Each object provided by an OLE server is uniquely identified by its program ID. These program IDs are stored in the system Registry as described in the OLE server's documentation. OLEObject:CreateEmbedding() creates an embedded OLE object from its program ID and loads it into an OLEObject container.
member.example:
The following code responds to a button click by creating an object with the program ID Word.Document.6 within an already existing OLEObject container sitting on a data window:
METHOD PushButton1() CLASS dw oDCOLEObject1:CreateEmbedding("Word.Document.6")

member.name: M:VO.OLEObject.CreateFromAppDocStorage
member.summary: Create an OLE object from an Application Doc File storage.
member.param: The OLEAppDocStorage object containing the object.
member.returns: TRUE if successful; otherwise, FALSE.
member.remarks: All OLE objects inserted into a form inside the Window Editor are saved inside a special file called the Application Doc File. When the OLE object is recreated at runtime, the persistent information is loaded from the Application Doc File using OLEObject:CreateFromAppDocStorage().

member.name: M:VO.OLEObject.CreateFromDBStorage
member.summary: Create an OLE object from a database storage.
member.param: The OLEDBStorage object describing the database storage.
member.returns: TRUE if successful; otherwise, FALSE.
member.remarks: X# supports the ability to store an OLE object in a DBF database. To assign a new value to the OLEObject container, you pass an OLEDBStorage object to OLEObject:CreateFromDBStorage(). To save the persistent information of an OLE object in the database, you pass an OLEDBStorage object to OLEObject:SaveToDBStorage(). You usually get the OLEDBStorage object as a result of a FieldGet() call.
member.example:
The following code shows how an OLEDBStorage object received from the FieldGet() call is used to create an OLE object and insert it into the OLEObject container:
LOCAL oDBStg AS OLEDBStorage oDBStg := FieldGet(FieldPos(#PaintObject)) oOLEContainer:CreateFromDBStorage(oDBStg)

member.name: M:VO.OLEObject.CreateFromInsertDialog
member.summary: Create an OLE object from the standard Insert Object dialog.
member.returns: TRUE if successful; otherwise, FALSE.
member.remarks: OLEObject:CreateFromInsertDialog() brings up the standard Insert Object dialog, allowing the user to select an object type which is then used to create a new OLE object for this OLEObject container.
member.example:
The following code first instantiates a new OLEObject container then uses OLEObject:CreateFromInsertDialog() to create an OLE object for the container. The OLEObject container is destroyed in case the OLE object creation failed — for example, because the user clicked on the dialog's Cancel button:
LOCAL oOLE AL OLEObject oOLE := DraggableOLEObject{SELF} oOLE:AllowInPlace := TRUE oOLE:AllowResize := TRUE IF oOLE:CreateFromInsertDialog() oOLE:Show() oOLE:SetFocus() ELSE oOLE:Destroy() ENDIF

member.name: M:VO.OLEObject.CreateFromOLEDragEvent
member.summary: Create an OLE object from an OLEDragEvent.
member.param: The OLEDragEvent object.
member.returns: TRUE if successful; otherwise, FALSE.
member.remarks: A window that is registered as an OLE drop target using ChileAppWindow:EnableOLEDropTarget() can handle OLE drag and drop events and create new OLE objects in response to such events. In the associated handlers, an OLEDragEvent object is passed as a parameter that can be used to create a new OLE object by calling OLEObject:CreateFromOLEDragEvent().
member.example:
The following code enables a data window as a drop target and creates a new OLE object inside its OLEDrop handler. It also checks the name of the OLE object to allow only WordPad documents:
METHOD EnableOLEDropTarget CLASS DropTargetDataWindow SELF:EnableOLEDropTarget(TRUE) METHOD OLEDrop(oOLEDragEvent) CLASS MyChild LOCAL oOLE AS OLEObject LOCAL lRet AS LOGIC IF oOLEDragEvent:ObjectName == "WordPad Document" oOLE := OLEObject{SELF} oOLE:AllowInPlace := TRUE oOLE:AllowResize := TRUE IF oOLE:CreateFromOLEDragEvent(oOLEDragEvent) oOLE:Origin := oOLEDragEvent:Position oOLE:Show() oOLE:SetFocus() ENDIF ENDIF

member.name: M:VO.OLEObject.CreateFromPasteDialog
member.summary: Create an OLE object from the standard Paste Special dialog.
member.returns: TRUE if successful; otherwise, FALSE.
member.remarks: OLEObject:CreateFromPasteDialog() brings up the standard Paste Special dialog, allowing the user to select an object from the Clipboard which is then used to create a new OLE object for this OLEObject container.
member.example:
The following code first instantiates a new OLEObject container then uses OLEObject:CreateFromPasteDialog() to create an OLE object for the container. The OLEObject container is destroyed in case the OLE object creation failed — for example, because the user clicked on the dialog's Cancel button:
LOCAL oOLE AS OLEObject oOLE := DraggableOLEObject{SELF} oOLE:AllowInPlace := TRUE oOLE:AllowResize := TRUE IF oOLE:CreateFromPasteDialog() oOLE:Show() oOLE:SetFocus() ELSE oOLE:Destroy() ENDIF
DataWindow:PasteSpecial(), OLEObject:CreateEmbedding(), OLEObject:CreateEmbeddingFromFile(), OLEObject:CreateFromAppDocStorage(), OLEObject:CreateFromDBStorage(), OLEObject:CreateFromInsertDialog(), OLEObject:CreateFromOLEDragEvent(), OLEObject:CreateLink()

member.name: M:VO.OLEObject.CreateLink
member.summary: Create an OLE object as a link to a file.
member.param: The name of file containing the OLE object.
member.returns: TRUE if successful; otherwise, FALSE.
member.remarks: A linked OLE object is stored outside the container's storage. This allows other applications to use and change the OLE object as well. OLEObject:CreateLink() creates a new linked OLE object and loads it into the OLEObject container.
member.example: The following code creates a linked OLE object from a text document into an OLEObject: oMyTextObject:CreateLink("\WINWORD\SAMPLE.DOC")

member.name: M:VO.OLEObject.Deactivate
member.summary: Deactivate an OLE object.
member.returns: TRUE if successful; otherwise, FALSE.
member.example:
The following code shows a push button's click event handler, which deactivates an OLEObject located on the same data window:
METHOD PushButton1() CLASS dw oDCOLEObject1:Deactivate("Word.Document.6")

member.name: M:VO.OLEObject.Destroy
member.summary: Provide a method to de-instantiate an OLEObject.
member.remarks: This method can be used when an OLEObject object is no longer needed. OLEObject:Destroy() de-instantiates the OLEObject object and allows you to close and free any resources that were opened or created by the object, without waiting for the garbage collector. The associated OLE object is automatically closed and the OLE object's server is shut down, unless it is serving other clients.

member.name: M:VO.OLEObject.DetachFromServer
member.summary: Remove a contained OLE object and cut the link to its server.
member.returns: TRUE if successful; otherwise, FALSE.
member.remarks: Since OLEObject serves as a container for any OLE object, it is possible to remove the current object, cut the link to its server, and load a new OLE object into the container by using one of the Create methods. In the process, OLEObject:DetachFromServer() removes the current OLE object and cuts the link to the object's server.

member.name: M:VO.OLEObject.Dispatch
member.summary: Provide the prototype dispatcher for events within the system when the control has focus; routing various events to their appropriate event handlers.
member.param: The event to be handled.
member.returns: TRUE if the event was handled; otherwise, FALSE.
member.remarks: OLEObject:Dispatch() serves as an internal callback, dispatching events to various event handlers. It should never be necessary to call this method directly. Instead, you can write your own Dispatch() method for derived classes if you want to handle additional events. Usually the derived class Dispatch() should call SUPER:Dispatch() to support the inherited event handling.

member.name: M:VO.OLEObject.DoVerb
member.summary: Exercise an OLE object's verb.
member.param: The verbs numerical ID.
member.returns: TRUE if successful; otherwise, FALSE.
member.remarks: A OLE object usually supports several actions (called verbs) which a user can perform on the object. An AVI object, for example, can support a Play and an Edit verb. The object's verbs can be invoked via the objects verb menu or directly by calling OLEObject:DoVerb().

member.name: M:VO.OLEObject.ExportToStorage
member.summary: Exports an OLE object to a user-managed storage file.
member.param: The name of the storage file.
The name of the storage.
member.example:
The following example is from the OLE Container application in \CAVO25\SAMPLES\OLE\CONT:
METHOD FileSave() CLASS Container LOCAL oOle AS OBJECT LOCAL oOD AS SaveAsDialog LOCAL i AS INT LOCAL s AS STRING (oOD := SaveAsDialog{SELF, "*.CDF"}):Show() s := oOD:FileNAme IF !Empty(oOD:FileName) SELF:Caption := oOD:FileName FOR i:= 1 TO ALen(aOLEObjects) oOle := aOLEObjects[i] oOle:ExportToStorage(oOd:FileName, "CONTAINEROBJECT_"+AllTrim(AsString(i))) NEXT ENDIF

member.name: M:VO.OLEObject.ImportFromStorage
member.summary: Imports an OLE object from a user-managed storage file.
member.param: The name of the storage file.
The name of the storage.
member.example:
The following example is from the OLE Container application in \CAVO25\SAMPLES\OLE\CONT:
METHOD FileLoad() CLASS ContainerShell LOCAL oOle AS DraggableOleObject LOCAL oOD AS OpenDialog LOCAL aStgNames AS ARRAY LOCAL i AS INT LOCAL oCont AS Container (oOD := OpenDialog{SELF, "*.CDF"}):Show() aStgNames := {} IF (!Empty(oOD:FileName) .and. GetStorageNames(oOD:FileName, aStgNames)) oCont := SELF:FileNew() oCont:Caption := oOD:FileName IF (oCont != NULL_OBJECT) FOR i:=1 TO ALen(aStgNames) oOle := DraggableOleObject{oCont} IF (oOle:ImportFromStorage(oOD:Filename, aStgNames[i])) oCont:SetupOLEObject(oOle, NIL, TRUE) ELSE oOle:Destroy() ENDIF NEXT ENDIF ENDIF

member.summary: Provide a general error interception that is automatically called whenever an assignment reference is made to a non-existent assign property. Important! NoIVarPut() should not be called directly; it is called by the system for handling invalid references.

The value to be assigned.

member.name: M:VO.OLEObject.No

member.name: M:VO.OLEObject.Redraw
member.summary: Cause the OLE object to redraw itself.
member.returns: TRUE if successful; otherwise, FALSE.

member.name: M:VO.OLEObject.Repaint
member.summary: Invalidate the OLE object so that an ExposeEvent is sent to the object.
member.remarks: The ExposeEvent triggers a redraw of the OLEObject container and its contained OLE object.

member.name: M:VO.OLEObject.SaveToDBStorage
member.summary: Save an OLE object into a database storage.
member.param: The OLEDBStorage object to use for the save operation.
member.returns: TRUE if successful; otherwise, FALSE.
member.remarks: X# supports the ability to store an OLE object in a DBF database. To assign a new value to the OLEObject container, you pass an OLEDBStorage object to OLEObject:CreateFromDBStorage(). To save the persistent information of an OLE object in the database, you pass an OLEDBStorage object to OLEObject:SaveToDBStorage(). You usually get the OLEDBStorage object as a result of a FieldGet() call.
member.example:
The following code shows how to load an OLE object form a database and save it back again:
LOCAL oDBStg AS OLEDBStorage oDBStg := FieldGet(FieldPos(#PaintObject)) oOLEContainer:CreateFromDBStorage(oDBStg) // do some editing with the OLE object oOLEContainer:SaveToDBStorage(oDBStg)

member.name: M:VO.OLEObject.SetHostNames
member.summary: Set the name of the container application and the current document.
member.param: The name of the container application.
The name of the current document.
member.returns: TRUE if successful; otherwise, FALSE.
member.remarks: These names are used during out-of-place editing in the server's window to identify the OLE object container application and the document in which it is located.

member.name: M:VO.OLEObject.UpdateTools
member.summary: Update the container's toolbars.
member.returns: TRUE if successful; otherwise, FALSE.
member.remarks: Whenever an OLE object is in-place active, the server's toolbars can replace the X# container application's toolbars. In response to a resizing of the container application, OLEObject:UpdateToolbars() causes the OLE object server to rearrange its toolbars.
member.example:
The following code shows how a X# container application uses OLEObject:UpdateToolbars() in response to a resize event:
METHOD Resize(oResizeEvent) CLASS MyShell LOCAL oOLE AS OBJECT LOCAL oChild AS MyChild SUPER:Resize(oResizeEvent) oChild := SELF:GetActiveMDIChildObject() IF oChild != NULL_OBJECT oOLE := oChild:GetActiveOLEObject() IF oOLE != NULL_OBJECT oOLE:UpdateTools() ENDIF ENDIF

member.name: M:VO.OLEShellWindow.Dispatch(XSharp.__Usual)
member.summary:
Note -
Provide the prototype dispatcher for events within the system when the OLE shell window has focus, routing various events to their appropriate event handlers. Important! This is a callback method used by X#. Normally, it should not be called in your application code.
member.param: The event to be handled.
member.returns: TRUE if the event was handled; otherwise, FALSE.
member.remarks: This method serves as an internal callback, dispatching events to various event handlers. It should never be necessary to call this method directly. Instead, you can write your own Dispatch() method for derived classes if you want to handle additional events. Usually the derived class Dispatch() should call SUPER:Dispatch() to support the inherited event handling. In addition to the functionality provided by the ShellWindow base class, the implementation for the OLEShellWindow class also includes support for handling in-place active OLE objects. For example, whenever the shell window is resized, it automatically asks the activated OLE objects to update their toolbars.

member.name: M:VO.OLEShellWindow.#ctor(XSharp.__Usual)

Construct an OLE shell window.
member.param: The window that owns the OLE shell window.

member.name: M:VO.Pen.#ctor(XSharp.__Usual,XSharp.__Usual,XSharp.__Usual)
member.summary: Construct a pen.

The pen's style, specified as one of the following constants:
Constant Description
LINECLEAR Invisible, which can be used to simplify the program logic. This is a shortcut to changing a point position without calling the MoveTo() and LineTo() functions (as in the code example under Pen class).
LINEDASHDOT Alternating dash/dot pattern.
LINEDASHDOTDOT A repeating sequence of a dash followed by two dots.
LINEDASHED Dashes.
LINEDOTTED Dots.
LINESOLID A continuous line. This is the default.
The pen's width, in canvas coordinates. The default is 1.
