member.name: M:VO.StatusBar.AddItem(XSharp.__Usual)
member.summary: Add a new item to the status bar.
member.param: The new item to add to the status bar.

member.name: M:VO.StatusBar.ClearItems
member.summary: Remove all of the status bar items.

member.name: M:VO.StatusBar.Destroy
member.summary: Provide a method to de-instantiate a StatusBar object.
member.remarks: This method can be used when a StatusBar object is no longer needed. StatusBar:Destroy() de-instantiates the StatusBar object and allows you to close and free any resources that were opened or created by the object, without waiting for the garbage collector.

member.name: M:VO.StatusBar.Disable
member.summary: Disable a status bar (until a subsequent call to StatusBar:Enable()).
member.remarks: Disabled status bars are not active and, therefore, they do not send events to their owner windows.

member.name: M:VO.StatusBar.DisplayKeyboard
member.summary: Enable the display of the keyboard state on the status bar.
member.remarks: The status bar refreshes the keyboard state itself, except for the insertion mode, which you must refresh by managing the StatusBar:InsertMode property. You must call this method before calling StatusBar:Show().

member.name: M:VO.StatusBar.DisplayMemory
member.summary: Enable the display of the virtual memory available, on the status bar. You must keep the display refreshed as necessary by calling StatusBar:RefreshMemoryDisplay().

member.name: M:VO.StatusBar.DisplayMessage
member.summary: Enable the display of messages on the status bar.

member.name: M:VO.StatusBar.DisplayPosition
member.summary: Enable the display of a coordinate pair on the status bar.
member.remarks: The pair is usually the mouse position, but you can supply any Pair object you like, such as a dimension or a point. You must keep the display refreshed as necessary by assigning pairs to the status bar's Position pseudo-variable. You must call this method before calling StatusBar:Show().

member.name: M:VO.StatusBar.DisplayTime
member.summary: Enable the digital clock display on the status bar.

member.name: M:VO.StatusBar.Enable
member.summary: Enable a status bar that was previously disabled.
member.remarks: Enabling a status bar allows it to generate events and to send the events to its owner window when the user manipulates the status bar. The dimming of disabled status bar is removed, and the status bar is restored to its normal appearance. By default, status bars are enabled until disabled, so there is no need to call this Enable() method unless StatusBar:Disable() was previously called.

member.name: M:VO.StatusBar.GetItemBoundingBox(XSharp.__Usual)
member.summary: Get the bounding box that describes the area of a status bar item.
member.param: The symbolic name of the status bar item whose bounding box will be returned. If omitted, the bounding box of the main message area will be returned.
member.returns: The bounding box for the specified item.

member.param: The type of handle required. 0 is the only supported option and is the default if <nHandleType> is omitted.
member.returns: A handle to the "window" (control), describing the underlying system object.
member.remarks: This method provides a handle to the window, which can then be used by Windows API calls.

member.name: M:VO.Stream.#ctor
member.summary: Construct a Stream object instance.
member.param: Pointer to an OLE stream.

member.name: M:VO.Stream.Read
member.summary: Read the next USUAL value from a stream.
member.returns: The next value (type USUAL) in the stream. The USUAL can hold any X# data, including nested arrays but not objects.
member.remarks: Stream:Read() can be used in ActiveXControl:StreamIn handlers to read USUAL values from the stream. You can use subsequent calls to Stream:Read() to read in as many values as have been saved to the stream by previous calls to Stream:Write(). Stream:Read() and Stream:Write() operations should be balanced and in the same order. For further details, see Creating OLE Servers in the "How To" section of the online help, as well as the sample applications that are accessible from the Samples tab page of the Application Gallery.
member.example:
This is from the StreamIn() method of the Calendar ActiveX sample that is accessible from the Samples tab page of the Application Gallery:
method StreamIn(oStream) class CalOCX local u as usual u := oStream:Read() if IsDate(u) curDate := u endif

member.name: M:VO.Stream.Write
member.summary: Write a USUAL value into a stream.
member.param: The USUAL value, which is written into the stream.
member.returns: TRUE, if the write operation was successful; otherwise, FALSE.
member.remarks: Stream:Write() can be used in ActiveXControl:StreamOut handlers to write USUAL values into the stream. You can use subsequent calls to Stream:Write() to write multiple values subsequently. Stream:Read() and Stream:Write() operations should be balanced and in the same order. For further details, see Creating OLE Servers in the "How To" section of the online help, as well as the sample applications that are accessible from the Samples tab page of the Application Gallery.
member.example:
This is from the StreamOut() method of the Calendar ActiveX sample that is accessible from the Samples tab page of the Application Gallery:
method StreamOut(oStream) class CalOCX oStream:Write(oOCXWindow:CurrentDate) return

member.name: M:VO.TextControl.SetCueBanner(XSharp.__Usual,XSharp.__Usual)
member.summary: Add a cue banner to the Edit control that has inherited from this class.
member.param: The text displayed as the cue.
The optional handle of the edit control to add the cue too. The default is the control that the method is called against.
member.remarks: A cue banner is text displayed in an edit control, usually indicating the purpose of the control or prompting for the type of input required. When the control gets focus or has text in it the cue is no longer displayed.

member.name: M:VO.TextControl.ShowEditBalloonTip(XSharp.__Usual,XSharp.__Usual,XSharp.__Usual,XSharp.__Usual)
member.summary: Add a BallonTip to the Edit control that has inherited from this class.
member.param: The title displayed in the tip.
The text displayed in the tip.
The icon to use in the tip.
The optional handle of the edit control to add the BalloonTip too. The default is the control that the method is called against.
member.remarks:
dwIcon can be:
Value Description
TTI_ERROR Use the error icon.
TTI_INFO Use the information icon.
TTI_NONE Use no icon.
TTI_WARNING Use the warning icon
A balloon tip can be displayed, pointing to an edit control.
The tip always points to the current cursor position within the control, and is dismissed by either clicking on it, by moving focus to a control other than the control the tip is assigned to, or by typing into the text box. Showing the tip automatically sets focus to the control at the last cursor position. A form can not show more than one tip at a time, and if the tip is repeatedly shown, the previous tip is destroyed first. Tips never get focus, and there is no message sent when the tip is dismissed. If the tip is not dismissed before the system timeout value for tool tips is reached, it automatically disappears leaving focus on the control.

member.name: M:VO.ToolBar.AddBand(XSharp.__Usual,XSharp.__Usual,XSharp.__Usual,XSharp.__Usual,XSharp.__Usual,XSharp.__Usual,XSharp.__Usual,XSharp.__Usual,XSharp.__Usual,XSharp.__Usual)
member.summary: Use this method to add a band to the ToolBar.
member.param: A symbol naming the band.
A window or control descendant to be included in the new band.
Position of the band. The default is the last position (-1).
Minimum width of the band.
Minimum height of the band.
Text to be displayed on the band.
A Color object specifying the foreground color of the band.
A Color object specifying the background color of the band.
An index into the image list specifying an image to be displayed.
A Bitmap object specifying a bitmap to be displayed as the band's background.
member.returns: TRUE, if the operation was successful; otherwise, FALSE.
member.remarks: The ToolBar:AddBand() method adds a new band to the toolbar. Bands are separate areas of a toolbar control, or window, which that can be resized and moved by the end user. Each band can hold a text, an image, and a control. Additionally, foreground and background colors, as well as a background bitmap, can be specified. If you want to create a band holding a sub-toolbar as a control, use ToolBar:AddSubToolBarBand().
member.example: For an example of a band-style toolbar, see the Private Eye sample application.

member.name: M:VO.ToolBar.AddSubToolBarBand(XSharp.__Usual,XSharp.__Usual,XSharp.__Usual,XSharp.__Usual)
member.summary: Add a new band to the toolbar as a sub-toolbar.
member.param: A symbol naming the main toolbar.
Position of the sub-toolbar band. The default is -1 (the last position).
Minimum width of the sub-toolbar band. The default is 100.

You are now able to pass a DWORD value to this parameter which allows you to create ToolBars with different styles inside a ReBar control.
TBSTYLE_TOOLTIPS:= 0x0100
TBSTYLE_WRAPABLE:= 0x0200
TBSTYLE_ALTDRAG:= 0x0400
TBSTYLE_FLAT:= 0x0800
TBSTYLE_LIST:= 0x1000
TBSTYLE_CUSTOMERASE:= 0x2000
TBSTYLE_REGISTERDROP:= 0x4000
TBSTYLE_TRANSPARENT:= 0x8000
member.returns: TRUE if successful; otherwise, FALSE.
member.remarks: The AddSubToolBarBand() method creates a new band holding its own toolbar. This way, you can create a toolbar that is divided into several bands, each holding a sub-toolbar.

member.summary: Add a string to be displayed as tip text for a button.
member.param: The button ID of the button to which to add the text.
The menu item ID of the button to which to add the text.

member.name: M:VO.ToolBar.AppendItem(XSharp.__Usual,XSharp.__Usual,XSharp.__Usual,XSharp.__Usual,XSharp.__Usual,XSharp.__Usual,XSharp.__Usual,XSharp.__Usual,XSharp.__Usual)
member.summary: Add a new toolbar button item to the end of the toolbar from the list of buttons available.
member.param:
The ID of the new toolbar button item. To add a gap between groups of buttons, append an item labeled IDT_SEPARATOR. To see the standard button items available, bring up the list in the Menu Editor.
For custom toolbar buttons, append an item labeled IDT_CUSTOMBITMAP. (For example, for the first button, the <nButtonID> is IDT_CUSTOMBITMAP + 1; the second is IDT_CUSTOMBITMAP + 2, and so on.)
The ID of the menu item corresponding to the new toolbar button item.

A bitmap object that contains one or more custom bitmaps. Each button in the bitmap must be a 16-color, 20 x 16 pixel bitmap. The first button in the bitmap must be drawn in pixel positions 1 and 20, the second in positions 21 and 40, the third in positions 41 and 60, and so on. (Effectively, this is a ribbon of buttons.)
It is possible to have the custom buttons in individual bitmap resource files, and create a Bitmap object for each button. <nPosition> is set to 1 if you use this method. It is recommended to use a ribbon of buttons in one bitmap file, as this only uses one handle. The latter method will use a handle for each object created.

The position of a custom toolbar button in the bitmap. If a ribbon of buttons is used for <oBitmap>, then the first button is 1, the second is 2, and so on. If an individual bitmap is used or if not specified, <nPosition> is 1.
The following figure illustrates a ribbon of buttons contained in one bitmap, showing the pixel positions and the <nPosition> for each:
The title of the toolbar button that is used if the button is displayed on the toolbar, in either of the TB_TEXTANDICON or TB_TEXTONLY styles. If not specified, the default is NULL_STRING.
The number of buttons in the image passed in <oBmp>. The default is 1.

The initial state of the button — enabled or disabled. If enabled, the button can be selected by the user. If disabled, the button appears dimmed (grayed) and cannot be selected; it remains unavailable until it is enabled by the application. The default is enabled (TBSTATE_ENABLED).

An optional style flag for the toolbar item. By default the style is automatically derived from the other parameters. Passing a Windows API constant can, however, enforce a specific style. The default is TBSTYLE_BUTTON.
Consult your Microsoft Win32 Software Development Kit documentation for detailed information about a particular Windows API constant.
Symbolic name representing the toolbar to be used. Defaults to the main toolbar.
member.returns: TRUE if successful; otherwise, FALSE.
member.remarks: Both the event triggered, when the button is clicked, and the description that shows up in the status bar are based on the properties of the associated menu. Thus, the toolbar controls the action of the application indirectly, through its associated menu. Specifying a toolbar by calling this method for each standard toolbar button might seem cumbersome. The recommended way to define the toolbar is to use the Menu Editor, which automatically generates code to lay out the toolbar. Note that the user can modify the set of button items on the toolbar with the configuration dialog. The program does not need to concern itself with what buttons exist, since the events come in as if they were menu selections. In order to reduce "visual noise" (undesirable blinking and flicker), the toolbar does not immediately reflect a button added with ToolBar:AppendItem(). Instead, you must call ToolBar:Update() to make all the new buttons show up at once. The ToolBar:Show() method automatically updates the display. For toolbars that are defined once and for all and attached to a window, there is no need for explicitly calling ToolBar:Update(), it is intended only for toolbars that change their button configuration on the fly.

member.name: M:VO.ToolBar.ChangeTipText(XSharp.__Usual,XSharp.__Usual,XSharp.__Usual)
member.summary: Change the current tip text for a button.
member.param: The ID of the button whose tip text you want to change. This is either the button ID or the menu item ID, depending on the value of <symLookup>.
The text that will replace the current tip text.

A symbol that describes how to interpret <nID>. If the value is #ButtonID, <nID> is the button ID of the button; otherwise, if the value is #MenuItemID, <nID> is the menu item ID of the button. If omitted, <nID> is interpreted as the button ID.
member.returns: TRUE if the text could be changed; otherwise, FALSE.

member.name: M:VO.ToolBar.ClickItem(XSharp.__Usual,XSharp.__Usual)
member.summary: Make a button look like it is has been clicked, indicating that it has been selected.
member.param:
The menu item ID corresponding to the button that is clicked.
This is not the original button ID that defines the look of the button; rather, it is the menu item ID which defines the meaning of the button.
member.remarks: ClickItem() and UnclickItem() are used to indicate status ("sticky" buttons). A toolbar button is normally clicked in (which turns the middle of the button black) and out (which returns the middle of the button to white) to indicate that its corresponding menu item has been checked or unchecked. A button retains its clicked-in state whether enabled or disabled.

member.remarks: This method enables or disables toolbar band support. If bands are enabled (the default), the toolbar uses internally a Rebar32 control and supports the management of several bands. If you do not need or want bands, issue EnableBands(FALSE) before the toolbar is shown/created. If band support is disabled, the band-related methods, such as ToolBar:AddBand(), will not work.

member.name: M:VO.ToolBar.#ctor(XSharp.__Usual,XSharp.__Usual,XSharp.__Usual,XSharp.__Usual,XSharp.__Usual)
member.summary: Create a toolbar.
member.param: The window that owns the toolbar.
The unique ID of the toolbar (between 1 and 8000).
The origin of the toolbar in canvas coordinates.
The dimension of the toolbar in canvas coordinates.

A flag specifying whether the toolbar supports bands. Band support is disabled if the flag is set to FALSE or if the application is running on a system with an old version of the Common Controls library. In this case, the band-related methods (AddBand(), AddSubToolBarBand(), etc.) are not available. The default is TRUE.
member.remarks: A toolbar is usually assigned to a window simply by attaching it to its corresponding menu; when the menu is assigned to the window, the toolbar is assigned as well. (It is also possible to explicitly assign a toolbar separately from its menu, using the AppWindow:ToolBar property.) Instantiating the toolbar does not make it visible and active. The toolbar becomes alive only when attached to a window in the same way as a menu. To reduce "visual noise"(undesirable blinking and flicker), the configuration of the buttons and layout of the toolbar should be completed before it is assigned to the window and made visible. To define the button layout of a toolbar, you use the AppendItem() and InsertItem() methods. Note that the item IDs must be coordinated with the corresponding menu item IDs. The easiest way to manage this correspondence is to use the Menu Editor, which automatically generates the corresponding code. A toolbar can be placed on any type of window. Note however, that the window takes up some of the area of the window, leaving less space to work with. Shell windows and data windows automatically adapt to the toolbar, but if you place a toolbar on another kind of window you need to accommodate the change explicitly. Use the ToolBar:ClientArea property to determine how much room is left.

member.name: M:VO.ToolBar.InsertItem(XSharp.__Usual,XSharp.__Usual,XSharp.__Usual,XSharp.__Usual,XSharp.__Usual,XSharp.__Usual)
member.summary: Insert a new toolbar button item before a specified toolbar button item, from the list of buttons available.
member.param: The ID of the new toolbar button item. To add a gap between groups of buttons, append an item labeled IDT_SEPARATOR. To see the button items available, see Appendix A or bring up a list in the Menu Editor.
The ID of the menu item corresponding to the new toolbar button item.
The ID of the toolbar button item before which the new toolbar button item should be inserted. If omitted, the new toolbar button item is inserted after the last toolbar button item.
member.returns: TRUE if successful; otherwise, FALSE.
member.remarks: Both the event triggered when the button is clicked and the description that shows up in the status bar are based on the properties of the associated menu. Thus, the toolbar controls the action of the application indirectly, through its associated menu. Specifying a toolbar by calling this method for each button might seem cumbersome. The recommended way to define the toolbar is to use the Menu Editor, which automatically generates code to lay out the toolbar. Note that the user can modify the set of button items on the toolbar with the configuration dialog. The program does not need to concern itself with what buttons exist, since the events come in as if they were menu selections. In order to reduce "visual noise" (undesirable blinking and flicker), the toolbar does not immediately reflect a button added with InsertItem(). Instead, you must call Update() to make all the new buttons show up at once. The Show() method automatically updates the display. For toolbars that are defined once and for all and attached to a window, there is no need for explicitly calling Update(), it is intended only for toolbars that change their button configuration on the fly.

member.name: M:VO.ToolBar.IsClicked(XSharp.__Usual,XSharp.__Usual,XSharp.__Usual)
member.summary: Return a logical value indicating whether the specified button is currently clicked or selected.
member.param: The ID of the desired toolbar button item.
Symbol indicating the type of data <nButtonID> represents. Valid values are #ButtonID and #MenuItemID. Defaults to #ButtonID.
Symbolic name representing the toolbar to be used. Defaults to the main toolbar.
member.returns: TRUE if clicked (or selected); otherwise, FALSE.

Symbolic name representing the toolbar to be used. Defaults to the main toolbar.

member.name: M:VO.ToolBar.SetImageList( )
member.summary: Sets the ImageList to be used by the ToolBar.
member.param: Can be an Imagelist or a bitmap loaded with LR_CREATEDIBSECTION and the background Color{192, 192, 192}.

Can be #IMAGELIST, #HOTIMAGELIST or #DISABLEDIMAGELIST,
The default value is #IMAGELIST

Is the name of the toolbar (subtoolbar)
The default is #Maintoolbar
member.remarks: You can assign your own imagelist for every subtoolbar. Additionally you could assign a separate HotImagelist and a DisabledImagelist for every subtoolbar. If you assign a Bitmap instead, it is automatically converted into a compatible Imagelist. Bitmaps for a toolbar imagelist must be loaded with the parameter LR_CREATEDIBSECTION and not with the BMP_3DTRANSPARENT which is needed for Ribbons. The Bitmap must have the default VO background color for Toolbar ribbons Color{192, 192, 192}.

member.name: M:VO.ToolBar.Show
member.summary: Display a toolbar so it is visible.
member.remarks: ToolBar:Show() is used to redisplay a toolbar that was hidden with the ToolBar:Hide() method. The toolbar does not have to be shown initially, it becomes visible as soon as it is assigned to a window.

member.name: M:VO.ToolBar.ShowItem(XSharp.__Usual,XSharp.__Usual)
member.summary: Show a button.
member.param: The menu item ID of the button to show.

member.name: M:VO.ToolBar.UnClickItem(XSharp.__Usual,XSharp.__Usual)
member.summary: Make a button look like it is "clicked-out" (returned to its normal state) after it has been "clicked-in" to indicate that it has been selected.
member.param:
The menu item ID corresponding to the button that is unclicked.
This is not the original button ID that defines the look of the button; rather it is the menu item ID which defines the meaning of the button.
member.remarks: ToolBar:ClickItem() and ToolBar:UnclickItem() are used to indicate status ("sticky" buttons). A toolbar button is normally clicked in (which turns the middle of the button black) and out (which returns the middle of the button to white) to indicate that its corresponding menu item has been checked or unchecked. A button retains its clicked-in state whether enabled or disabled.

member.summary: Collapse a tree view item, hiding its child items.
member.param: The symbolic name of the tree view item to be collapsed.
The TreeViewItem object representing the tree view item to be collapsed.
A logical value indicating whether child tree view items of the specified item will be removed when the item is collapsed. If omitted, the default is FALSE.
If lAll is TRUE(default = FALSE), the operation is done for the complete subtree of the specified item.

If lForceNotify is TRUE(default = FALSE), a notify message Window:TreeViewItemExpanding() and Window:TreeViewItemExpanded() is sent for each item whose expand state is changed.
Generally windows will only send these messages when an item is first expanded. It depends on the TVIS_EXPANDEDONCE state. (see in Platform SDK the TVM_EXPAND Message for more details.)
member.returns: TRUE if successful; otherwise, FALSE.

member.name: M:VO.Window.Activate(XSharp.__Usual)
member.summary: Provide a method that is invoked when this window is activated. Important! This is a callback method used by X#. Normally, it should not be called in your application code.
member.param: The event that describes which window was activated.
member.remarks:
The Activate() event occurs at the start of the window's lifetime or when the window is activated after it has been deactivated (for example, by clicking on it with the mouse). The newly active window receives the input focus.
You should create and show cursors (if needed) in this event handler method. Any subclass with its own Activate() and Deactivate() event handlers should always call its owner's handlers. This ensures that the caption bars get highlighted or dimmed accordingly.

member.name: M:VO.Window.AddTrayIcon(XSharp.__Usual,XSharp.__Usual,XSharp.__Usual)
member.summary: Adds a tray icon associated with the window.
member.param: The icon object to add to the tray.
The unique ID of the icon (between 1 and 8000).
The tool tip string to be displayed for this icon.

remarks.note: If Shell version 5 or above is loaded, the tool tip will support line breaks by using CRLF. On older versions of the Shell the CRLF is automatically replaced with a space.

member.name: M:VO.Window.AnimationStart(XSharp.__Usual)
member.summary: Provide a method that is invoked when an animation control begins playback. Important! This is a callback method used by X#. Normally, it should not be called in your application code.
member.param: The ControlNotifyEvent object that describes which animation control started playback.

member.name: M:VO.Window.AnimationStop(XSharp.__Usual)
member.summary: Provide a method that is invoked when an animation control ends playback. Important! This is a callback method used by X#. Normally, it should not be called in your application code.
member.param: The ControlNotifyEvent object that describes which animation control ended playback.

member.name: M:VO.Window.AppCommand(XSharp.__Usual)
member.summary: Provide a method that is invoked when an AppCommand event takes place. Important! This is a callback method used by X#. Normally, it should not be called in your application code.
member.param: The AppCommandEvent object that describes the event which was initiated.
member.remarks: This event must be overridden in the application and must return TRUE to complete the processing.

member.name: M:VO.Window.ButtonClick(XSharp.__Usual)
member.summary: Provide a method that is invoked when a check box, push button, or radio button is clicked with the mouse. Important! This is a callback method used by X#. Normally, it should not be called in your application code.
member.param: The ControlEvent object that describes which button was clicked.
member.remarks: Button click events (radio, check, and push buttons) are propagated to the window's owner the same way as MenuEvents. For an in-depth discussion on command event propagation, refer to the Programmer's Guide. You must supply the code to turn a radio button on (and all the other radio buttons off) when a user clicks on a radio button. Similarly, you must also be sure to invert the state of a check box when it is clicked.
member.example:
This is a typical example of responding to various button clicks:
METHOD ButtonClick(oControlEvent) CLASS TeamInfo LOCAL oControl AS Control LOCAL sSym AS SYMBOL oControl := IIf(oControlEvent == NULL_OBJECT, NULL_OBJECT, ; oControlEvent:Control) SUPER:ButtonClick(oControlEvent) //Put your changes here sSym := oControl:nameSym DO CASE CASE sSym == #cbHasSponsor // a checkbox IF SELF:oDCcbHasSponsor:checked SELF:oDCsleSponsorName:enable() ELSE SELF:oDCsleSponsorName:TextValue := SPACE(25) SELF:oDCsleSponsorName:disable() ENDIF CASE sSym == #rbRecreational .or. sSym == #rbCompetition // radio buttons // Do something in here ENDCASE

member.name: M:VO.Window.ButtonDoubleClick(XSharp.__Usual)
member.summary: Provide a method that is invoked when a check box, push button, or radio button is double-clicked. Important! This is a callback method used by X#. Normally, it should not be called in your application code.
member.param: The ControlEvent that describes which button was double-clicked.

member.name: M:VO.Window.CanvasErase
member.summary: Erase the current canvas area of this window and repaint it using either the background brush or the system's default background color.

member.name: M:VO.Window.Close(XSharp.__Usual)
member.summary: Invoked just as the window is about to close. Important! This is a callback method used by X#. Normally, it should not be called in your application code.
member.param: An empty event required to maintain the protocol that all event handlers have exactly one event as their argument.
member.remarks: Note that this method is automatically called when an EndDialog() or EndWindow() method is called.

member.name: M:VO.Window.ComboBoxExEndEdit(XSharp.__Usual)
member.summary: A callback method that is invoked when a ComboBoxEx control sends an 'EndEdit' notification message Important! This is a callback method used by X#. Normally, it should not be called in your application code.
member.remarks: Provide a method that is invoked when a ComboBoxEx controls sends a CBEN_ENDEDIT message.

member.name: M:VO.Window.ComboBoxExNotify(XSharp.__Usual)
member.summary: A callback method that is invoked when a ComboBoxEx control sends a notification message Important! This is a callback method used by X#. Normally, it should not be called in your application code.
member.param: An event that has the information about the notify event
member.remarks: Provide a method that is invoked when a ComboBoxEx control sends one of the following notification messages. CBEN_INSERTITEM, CBEN_DELETEITEM, CBEN_DRAGBEGIN, CBEN_BEGINEDIT and CBEN_ENDEDIT Currently this method contains only a message handler for the CBEN_ENDEDIT message, which calls the Window:ComboBoxExEndEdit() method. If you override this method to process the other messages, don’t forget to call SUPER: ComboBoxExNotify(oControlNotifyEvent) in the otherwise part.

member.name: M:VO.Window.ControlNotify(XSharp.__Usual)
member.summary: Provide a method that is invoked when a control sends a notification to its parent window. Important! This is a callback method used by X#. Normally, it should not be called in your application code.
member.param: The ControlNotifyEvent object that describes which control sent the notification.
member.remarks: This is a general method that is called whenever a common control sends a notification to its parent window. In many cases, a more specific method is invoked in addition to this method in response to the notification. Notifiy codes that are not handled by this method are send to the Control:ParentNotify() method when this method is available.

member.name: M:VO.Window.DateTimeSelectionChanged(XSharp.__Usual)
member.summary: Provide a method that is invoked when a DateTimePicker selection is changed. Important! This is a callback method used by X#. Normally, it should not be called in your application code.

member.name: M:VO.Window.DeActivate(XSharp.__Usual)
member.summary: Provide a method that is invoked when this window is deactivated. Important! This is a callback method used by X#. Normally, it should not be called in your application code.
member.param: An empty event required to maintain the protocol that all event handlers have exactly one event as their argument.
member.remarks: This event handler is normally invoked when another application or window becomes activated. If Window:MouseTrapOn() is left on, MouseEvent events cannot be directed to other applications or windows.

member.name: M:VO.Window.DeactivateAllOLEObjects(XSharp.__Usual)
member.summary: Deactivate all currently active OLE objects.
member.remarks: The DeactivateAllOLEObjects() method deactivates any currently (in-place) active OLE objects. The method is called automatically whenever the window itself is deactivated.

member.name: M:VO.Window.Destroy
member.summary: Free memory resources allocated for a window and its derived objects.
member.remarks: This method immediately frees resources for Window objects created explicitly in your application. Window:Destroy() also takes care of resources allocated to derived classes and deallocates them in the necessary order (e.g., child windows are destroyed before the parent window, dialog windows and MDI shell windows are also looked after).

member.name: M:VO.Window.Disable
member.summary: Disable this window (until a subsequent call to Enable()).
member.remarks: Disabled windows no longer receive mouse and keyboard events.

member.name: M:VO.Window.DispatchUnknown
member.summary: Handle messages that are not processed by the window. Important! This is a callback method used by X#. Normally, it should not be called in your application code.
member.remarks: You can now write a Window:DispatchUnknown( oEvent ) to handle messages that are not processed by the window.

member.name: M:VO.Window.Draw(XSharp.__Usual)
member.summary: Display a Draw object on this window.
member.param: The object to be drawn.
The array of objects to be drawn.
member.remarks: A Draw object is drawn by placing the device context or presentation space into the Draw object and then calling the Draw object's method Draw(). This is the only valid way of drawing a Draw object on a window.

member.name: M:VO.Window.DrawBackground(XSharp.__Usual,XSharp.__Usual)
member.summary: Draw the background of a window.
member.param: The handle of the device context.

The window to be drawn.
The oWindow object is normally identical with SELF except when SELF is a DataWindow. In this case oWindow should be the oSurface (__FormDialogWindow) object. In a DataWindow you should draw the background only if oWindow == oSurface, otherwise it is superfluous.
member.remarks: If you draw the background for yourself you should return TRUE otherwise FALSE.

member.name: M:VO.Window.Drop
member.summary: Retrieve information about a load from the drag event and act on each file in the selection. Important! This is a callback method used by X#. Normally, it should not be called in your application code.
member.param: The DragEvent that determines the position of the mouse (in canvas coordinates), as well as the number and names of files, in the drag-and-drop load.
member.remarks: The system dispatches this method when the user lets go of the mouse button to drop the load in the client area. This method is required to handle drag-and-drop correctly. It retrieves information about the load from the drag event and acts on each file in the selection.

member.name: M:VO.Window.EditChange(XSharp.__Usual)
member.summary: Provide a method that is invoked when the text in an edit control is changed. Important! This is a callback method used by X#. Normally, it should not be called in your application code.
member.param: The ControlEvent object that describes which edit control was changed.

member.name: M:VO.Window.EditFocusChange(XSharp.__Usual)
member.summary: Provide a method that is invoked when the input focus changes to or from an edit control. Important! This is a callback method used by X#. Normally, it should not be called in your application code.
member.param: The EditFocusChangeEvent object that identifies which edit control generated the EditFocusChangeEvent object and whether it has just gained or lost the keyboard focus.
member.remarks: If Window:EditFocusChange() is used to validate an edit control (and also return the focus to it if invalid), Control:SetFocus() should not be called until another control has received the focus. In complex dialog windows that contain many edit controls, it makes sense to grab the edit control's text when the focus is changing so that other controls can be updated with it if necessary. See the ButtonClick() method for an example of similar syntax to be used in this method. Note that none of the button controls are passed through this method, only SingleLineEdit and MultiLineEdit controls. If looking to control Combobox selections, then use the ListBoxSelect() callback method.

member.name: M:VO.Window.EditScroll(XSharp.__Usual)
member.summary: Provide a method that is invoked for this window when an edit control is scrolled. Important! This is a callback method used by X#. Normally, it should not be called in your application code.
member.param: The ControlEvent object that identifies which edit control invoked the event handler.
member.remarks:
This type of event normally happens when the user enters more characters in an edit control than it can display.
In Windows, you must set flags in the resource entity description of the edit control to allow scrolling:
Constant Description
ES_AUTOHSCROLL Automatically scrolls the text horizontally
ES_AUTOVSCROLL Automatically scrolls the text vertically
WS_HSCROLL Displays a horizontal scroll bar on the edit control
WS_VSCROLL Displays a vertical scroll bar on the edit control

member.name: M:VO.Window.Enable
member.summary: Enable a previously disabled window.
member.remarks: Enabling a window allows it to receive mouse and keyboard events. By default, windows are enabled until disabled, so there is no need to call the Window:Enable() method unless Window:Disable() was previously called.

member.name: M:VO.Window.EnableDragDropClient(XSharp.__Usual)
member.summary: Allow "draggable" windows to be dropped on this window.
member.param: TRUE enables the window as a drop client. FALSE does not allow this behavior. If omitted, the default is TRUE.

member.name: M:VO.Window.EnableDragDropServer(XSharp.__Usual)
member.summary: Allow this window to be dropped on windows with drag and drop capabilities.
member.param: TRUE enables the window as a drag server. FALSE does not allow this behavior. If omitted, the default is TRUE.

member.name: M:VO.Window.EnableHelp(XSharp.__Usual,XSharp.__Usual)
member.summary: Enable or disable help for a window and its child windows.
member.param: TRUE enables help; FALSE disables help. If not specified, the default is TRUE.
A HelpDisplay object specifying the help file to use.
member.remarks: This method is called by Window:HelpDisplay().

member.name: M:VO.Window.EnableHelpButton
member.summary: Enables the help button in the window caption bar.
member.remarks: Enables the help button in the window caption bar. This works only if no maximize or minimize button is present on the caption bar. It is recommended for DialogWindow’s. This is recommended only, if you have created the HelpDisplay{} object with lWin32Processing is TRUE.

member.name: M:VO.Window.EnableHelpCursor
member.summary: Changes the cursor to a question mark with a pointer.
member.remarks: Changes the cursor to a question mark with a pointer. If the user then clicks a control the control receives a help request message. This is recommended only, if you have created the HelpDisplay{} object with lWin32Processing is TRUE.

member.name: M:VO.Window.EnableThemeDialogTexture(XSharp.__Usual)
member.summary: Enables or disables the visual style of a dialog window's background.
member.param: The style to be set.
Description
Enables dialog window background texturing. The texturing is defined by a visual style.
Enables dialog window background texturing. The texture is the Tab control texture defined by the visual style. This flag is equivalent to (ETDT_ENABLE | ETDT_USETABTEXTURE).
Disables background texturing.
Uses the Tab control texture for the background texture of a dialog window.
member.remarks: This method allows the enabling and disableing of background themes in WinXP and later.

member.name: M:VO.Window.EnableToolTips(XSharp.__Usual)
member.summary: Enable or disable the tooltips for a window. Note that assigning a value to Control:ToolTipText automatically enables the tooltip's display on the parent window.
member.param: Logical value indicating whether the tool tips should be enabled (TRUE) or disabled (FALSE). If omitted, the default is TRUE.
member.returns: TRUE, if tooltips were enabled; FALSE, if tooltips were disabled.

member.name: M:VO.Window.Expose(XSharp.__Usual)
member.summary: Provide a method that is invoked whenever part of the window needs repainting. Important! This is a callback method used by X#. Normally, it should not be called in your application code.
member.param: The ExposeEvent object that describes which area of the window needs repainting.
member.remarks:
This is one of the most important event handlers. A window requires repainting when the window: Is partially uncovered by another window Is first shown Increases in size Is being restored after being iconized The window should retain enough information to redraw the screen as it was (or as it should be).
An ExposeEvent is also triggered by calling Repaint() or Update(); you should not call Repaint() or Update() during the Expose().

member.name: M:VO.Window.FocusChange(XSharp.__Usual)
member.summary: Provide a method that is invoked when the input focus changes from the current window to another (or vice versa). Important! This is a callback method used by X#. Normally, it should not be called in your application code.
member.param: The FocusChangeEvent object that identifies whether the focus is being gained or lost.
member.remarks: If your window uses cursors, you should hide the window's cursor when the focus is changed to a different window, and then show the cursor when the window receives focus again. This should be used in conjunction with the Window:Activate() and Window:Deactivate() event handlers.
member.example:
This example demonstrates how Window:FocusChange() displays the cursor at the specified cursor position when focus is gained. If the focus is lost, the cursor is hidden:
METHOD FocusChange(oFocusChangeEvt) CLASS MyTopAppWindow IF(oFocusChangeEvt:GotFocus) // Gaining focus oMyCursor:Show() oMyCursor:Position := oMyCursorPos ELSE // Losing focus oMyCursorPos := oMyCursor:Position oMyCursor:Hide() ENDIF

member.name: M:VO.Window.GetAllChildren
member.summary: Obtain an array of all X# children objects of the window.
member.returns: An array of all X# children objects of the window. This array may contain window objects as well as control objects. Note that controls which do not have a corresponding X# object, like a FixedText control where the Generate Code property was set to "No", are not included in the returned array.

member.name: M:VO.Window.GetStyle
member.summary: Retrieve the styles for the window.
member.returns: Numeric value representing the X# style constants or Windows API style constants enabled for the window.

member.name: M:VO.Window.Handle
member.summary: Return the handle for a window.
member.param: The type of handle required. 0 is the only supported option and is the default if <nHandleType> is omitted.
member.returns: A handle to the window, describing the underlying system object.
member.remarks: This method provides a handle to the window, which can then be used by Windows API calls.

member.name: M:VO.Window.HelpRequest(XSharp.__Usual)
member.summary: Provide a method that is invoked when the user requests help from the application using one of the available context-sensitive help mechanisms. Important! This is a callback method used by X#. Normally, it should not be called in your application code.
member.param: The HelpRequestEvent object that describes which item help is being requested for.
member.remarks: This event handler is invoked only if the help mechanism has been enabled for the current window (or one of its owners). The help mechanism is enabled by assigning a HelpDisplay object to the windows HelpDisplay property. The default implementation of this event handler is to display the help topic that is associated with the control, menu command, or window region with focus when the HelpRequestEvent was generated. This is accomplished using HelpDisplay:Show(<cKeyword>), where <cKeyword> is either a HyperLabel:HelpContext property or a default keyword generated by this event handler in cases where a hyperlabel is not available. If there is no hyperlabel for an item, the keyword generated is as follows: A HELPCONTROL request generates the keyword Control_xxxx, where xxxx is the numeric ID of the control, in decimal. For example, an OK push button might generate the keyword Control_101. A HELPMENU request generates the keyword Menu_xxxx, where xxxx is the "cleaned" text of the menu command. The cleaned text has all leading and trailing spaces and the ampersand character (&) removed. In addition, all sequences of spaces are replaced by a single underscore, and the string is truncated at the first tab character. For example, the keyword generated for the menu command: Save &As\tF3 is Menu_Save_As A HELPWINDOW request generates one of the keywords listed in the table below, depending on the window region that has focus: Keyword Window Region Window_Border Border Window_Caption Title bar Window_MaxBox Maximize button Window_MinBox Minimize button Window_SysMenuBox System menu button Window_Unknown Any area of the window not explicitly identified in this table Window_WindowCanvas Canvas area If the Window_Unknown keyword is generated, the default behavior of HelpRequest() is to display the Contents topic as defined in the HelpDisplay (that is, HelpDisplay:Show("HelpIndex")). If a HELPWINDOW request is received, while Window:HelpContext is defined, Window:HelpRequest() uses the HelpContext property, regardless of the window region that has focus. Refer to the "GUI Classes" chapter in the Programmer's Guide for more information on programming an online help system for your application.

member.name: M:VO.Window.Hide
member.summary: Hide this window so it is not visible.
member.remarks: The window remains hidden from display until the Window:Show() method is called. This method is not used to close a window. Use Window:Hide() to make a window disappear from view, but remain available for re-opening.

member.name: M:VO.Window.HorizontalScroll(XSharp.__Usual)
member.summary: Provide a method that is invoked when a horizontal scroll bar is scrolled. Important! This is a callback method used by X#. Normally, it should not be called in your application code.
member.param: The ScrollEvent object that describes the scroll type and new position.
member.remarks: The default behavior for this event handler is to update the thumb position; this can be changed using your own implementation of the handler. This event handler only works for HorizontalScrollBar and WindowHorizontalScrollBar objects. If the application has vertical scroll bars, use a WindowVerticalScrollBar event handler.

member.name: M:VO.Window.HorizontalSlide(XSharp.__Usual)
member.summary: Provide a method that is invoked when a horizontal slider's thumb is dragged either by the mouse or the keyboard. Important! This is a callback method used by X#. Normally, it should not be called in your application code.
member.param: The SliderEvent object that describes which horizontal slider's thumb was dragged.

member.name: M:VO.Window.HorizontalSpin(XSharp.__Usual)
member.summary: Provide a method that is invoked when a horizontal spinner is spun. Important! This is a callback method used by X#. Normally, it should not be called in your application code.
member.param: The SpinnerEvent object that describes which horizontal spinner was spun.

member.name: M:VO.Window.#ctor(XSharp.__Usual)
member.summary: Construct a Window object.
member.param: The window that owns this window.
member.remarks: The window initialization code generated by the Window Editor calls PreInit() and PostInit() at the beginning and the end, respectively, of the Init() method. The default implementation returns NIL. Implementation of PreInit()/PostInit(), however, results in customized initialization code which is not overridden by the Window Editor's code generation.

member.name: M:VO.Window.IsIconic
member.summary: Report if this window is currently iconized.
member.returns: TRUE if the window is iconized; otherwise, FALSE.

member.name: M:VO.Window.IsVisible
member.summary: Report if this window is visible (completely or partially) or hidden.
member.returns: TRUE if the window is visible; otherwise, FALSE.

member.name: M:VO.Window.IsZoomed
member.summary: Report if this window is maximized (fills the entire screen).
member.returns: TRUE if the window is maximized; otherwise, FALSE.

member.name: M:VO.Window.KeyDown(XSharp.__Usual)
member.summary: Provide a method that is invoked when a key on the keyboard is pressed. Important! This is a callback method used by X#. Normally, it should not be called in your application code.
member.param: The KeyEvent object that describes what key was pressed.
member.remarks: This event handler is called only if the window has the input focus. In addition, it is rarely overridden due to the existence of edit controls. If it is overridden for a dialog window, it should call the owner handler (this ensures that tabbing to controls in Windows still works).

member.name: M:VO.Window.KeyUp(XSharp.__Usual)
member.summary: Provide a method that is invoked when a key on the keyboard is released. Important! This is a callback method used by X#. Normally, it should not be called in your application code.
member.param: The KeyEvent object that describes what key was released.
member.remarks: This event handler is called only if the window has the input focus.

member.name: M:VO.Window.LineTo(XSharp.__Usual)
member.summary: Draw a line on this window (using the current pen) from the current pen position to a specified point.
member.param: The position where the line should end, in canvas coordinates.
An array of points, in canvas coordinates, where the line should end, in which case Window:LineTo() acts like a polyline method.
member.remarks: The current pen position is updated to the line's ending position (as specified by <oPoint> or <aoPoint>).

member.name: M:VO.Window.ListBoxClick(XSharp.__Usual)
member.summary: Provide a method that is invoked when an item in a list box owned by this window is double-clicked. Important! This is a callback method used by X#. Normally, it should not be called in your application code.
member.param: The ControlEvent object that describes which list box contained the item that is double-clicked.

member.name: M:VO.Window.ListBoxSelect(XSharp.__Usual)
member.summary: Provide a method that is invoked when an item in a list box owned by this window is clicked. Important! This is a callback method used by X#. Normally, it should not be called in your application code.
member.param: The ControlEvent object that describes which list box contained the item that was clicked.
member.example:
Typical example below of using this method:
METHOD ListBoxSelect(oControlEvent) CLASS TeamInfo LOCAL oControl AS Control LOCAL sSym AS SYMBOL oControl := IIf(oControlEvent == NULL_OBJECT, NULL_OBJECT, ; oControlEvent:Control) SUPER:ListBoxSelect(oControlEvent) //Put your changes here sSym := oControl:nameSym IF sSym == #cbxTeamNumbers IF SELF:cLastTeamNr != SELF:oDCcbxTeamNumbers:Value SELF:cLastTeamNr := SELF:oDCcbxTeamNumbers:Value SELF:BreakDownTeamNumber( SELF:oDCcbxTeamNumbers:Value ) ENDIF ENDIF

member.name: M:VO.Window.ListViewColumnClick(XSharp.__Usual)
member.summary: Provide a method that is invoked when a list view column header is clicked in a list view control.
member.param: The ListViewColumnClickEvent object that describes which list view column of which list view control was clicked.

member.name: M:VO.Window.ListViewItemChanging(XSharp.__Usual)
member.summary: Provide a method that is invoked when the state of a list view item is about to change. Important! This is a callback method used by X#. Normally, it should not be called in your application code.
member.param: The ListViewItemEvent object that describes which list view item is about to change.
member.remarks: The ListViewItemChanging event handler notifies a list view control's parent window that an item is about to be changed.

member.name: M:VO.Window.ListViewItemChanged(XSharp.__Usual)
member.summary: Provide a method that is invoked when a list view item has changed. Important! This is a callback method used by X#. Normally, it should not be called in your application code.
member.param: The ListViewItemEvent object that describes which list view item has changed.
member.remarks: The ListViewItemChanged event handler notifies a list view control's parent window that an item has changed.

member.name: M:VO.Window.ListViewItemDelete(XSharp.__Usual)
member.summary: Provide a method that is invoked when a list view item is deleted in a list view control. Important! This is a callback method used by X#. Normally, it should not be called in your application code.
member.param: The ListViewDeleteEvent object that describes which list view item of which list view control was deleted.

member.name: M:VO.Window.ListViewItemDrag(XSharp.__Usual)
member.summary: Provide a method that is invoked when a list view item is dragged in a list view control. Important! This is a callback method used by X#. Normally, it should not be called in your application code.
member.param: The ListViewDragEvent object that describes which list view item of which list view control was dragged.

member.name: M:VO.Window.ListViewItemEdit(XSharp.__Usual)
member.summary: Provide a method that is invoked when a list view item is edited in a list view control. Important! This is a callback method used by X#. Normally, it should not be called in your application code.
member.param: The ListViewEditEvent object that describes which list view item of which list view control was edited.

member.name: M:VO.Window.ListViewKeyDown(XSharp.__Usual)
member.summary: Provide a method that is invoked when a key is pressed in a list view control. Important! This is a callback method used by X#. Normally, it should not be called in your application code.
member.param: The ListViewKeyEvent object that describes which list view control received a key press.

member.name: M:VO.Window.ListViewMouseButtonDown(XSharp.__Usual)
member.summary: Provide a method that is invoked when a mouse button is clicked in a list view control. Important! This is a callback method used by X#. Normally, it should not be called in your application code.
member.param: The ListViewMouseEvent object that describes which list control received a mouse button click.
member.example:
Typical example of a ListViewMouseButtonDown usage. Note that in the example, the item's record number is stored in the "value" of the LVI, whereas the text of the item is stored in the "text" entity. Obviously this will only work when using a string-type column in the ListView for storing the record number also.
METHOD ListViewMouseButtonDown(oListViewMouseEvent) CLASS CoachesBrowse LOCAL sSym AS SYMBOL LOCAL oLVI AS ListViewItem SUPER:ListViewMouseButtonDown(oListViewMouseEvent) //Put your changes here oLVI := oListViewMouseEvent:ListViewItem sSym := oListViewMouseEvent:NameSym DO CASE CASE sSym == #lvCoaches IF oLVI != NULL_OBJECT IF oListViewMouseEvent:PointOnItem SELF:iCoachRec := oLVI:GetValue( #cCoachName ) SELF:cSelCoach := oLVI:GetText( #cCoachName ) SELF:oDbCoaches:GoTo( SELF:iCoachRec ) ENDIF ENDIF ENDCASE

member.name: M:VO.Window.ListViewMouseButtonDoubleClick(XSharp.__Usual)
member.summary: Provide a method that is invoked when a mouse button is double-clicked in a list view control. This could be used to invoke an "edit screen" for the selected item, print a report, etc. See the ListViewMouseButtonDown() method for sample syntax. Important! This is a callback method used by X#. Normally, it should not be called in your application code.
member.param: The ListViewMouseEvent object that describes which list control received a mouse button double-click.

member.name: M:VO.Window.MenuCommand(XSharp.__Usual)
member.summary: Provide a method that is invoked when an item on a menu owned by this window is selected. Important! This is a callback method used by X#. Normally, it should not be called in your application code.
member.param: The MenuCommandEvent object that describes which menu and menu command (via the item's ID) generated the event.

member.name: M:VO.Window.MenuInit(XSharp.__Usual)
member.summary: Provide a method that is invoked when a pop-up menu owned by this window is about to "pop up." Important! This is a callback method used by X#. Normally, it should not be called in your application code.
member.param: The MenuInitEvent object that describes which menu is about to pop up.
member.remarks: This event handler can be used to initialize menu commands, check items, and so forth.

member.name: M:VO.Window.MenuSelect(XSharp.__Usual)
member.summary: Provide a method that is invoked when an item on a menu owned by this window is selected. Important! This is a callback method used by X#. Normally, it should not be called in your application code.
member.param: The MenuSelectEvent object that describes which menu and menu command (via the item's ID) generated the event.
member.remarks: One use for this event handler is to provide more extensive help with the user's current selection. Selecting a menu command does not necessarily imply that it is invoked, only that the menu highlight bar is currently over this item.

member.name: M:VO.Window.MinMaxInfo(XSharp.__Usual)
member.summary: Provide a method that is invoked when the size or position of a window is about to change (cf WM_GETMINMAXINFO in Win API). Important! This is a callback method used by X#. Normally, it should not be called in your application code.
member.param: The MinMaxInfoEvent object that describes the maximised width, height and position of the maximised window in addition to the minimum and maximum height and width of the window.

member.name: M:VO.Window.ModifyTrayIcon(XSharp.__Usual,XSharp.__Usual,XSharp.__Usual)
member.summary: Modify the tray icon associated with the window.
member.param: The icon object to add to the tray.
The unique ID of the icon (between 1 and 8000).
The tool tip string to be displayed for this icon.

remarks.note: If Shell version 5 or above is loaded, the tool tip will support line breaks by using CRLF. On older versions of the Shell the CRLF is automatically replaced with a space.

member.name: M:VO.Window.MonthCalSelectionChanged(XSharp.__Usual)
member.summary: Provide a method that is invoked when the selection of a MonthCalendar control is changed. Important! This is a callback method used by X#. Normally, it should not be called in your application code.
member.param: The MonthCalSelectionEvent object that describes the changed selection.

member.name: M:VO.Window.MouseButtonDoubleClick(XSharp.__Usual)
member.summary: Provide a method that is invoked when the mouse pointer is positioned over the window and a mouse button is double-clicked. Important! This is a callback method used by X#. Normally, it should not be called in your application code.
member.param: The MouseEvent object that contains information about the state of the mouse when the button was double-clicked.
member.remarks: MouseButtonDoubleClick() often occurs between MouseButtonDown() and MouseButtonUp() event handlers.

member.name: M:VO.Window.MouseButtonDown(XSharp.__Usual)
member.summary: Provide a method that is invoked when the mouse pointer is positioned over the window and a mouse button is clicked. Important! This is a callback method used by X#. Normally, it should not be called in your application code.
member.param: The MouseEvent object that contains information about the state of the mouse when the button was clicked.
member.remarks: Use the Window:MouseTrapOn() method to force MouseEvents generated outside the canvas area to be directed to this window.

member.name: M:VO.Window.MouseButtonUp(XSharp.__Usual)
member.summary: Provide a method that is invoked when the mouse pointer is positioned over the window and a mouse button is released. Important! This is a callback method used by X#. Normally, it should not be called in your application code.
member.param: The MouseEvent object that contains information about the state of the mouse when the button was released.
member.remarks: Do not assume Window:MouseButtonUp() is called immediately after Window:MouseButtonDown(). Other MouseEvents can be generated during this time. In some cases, there may be no Window:MouseButtonUp() events directed to the window for a corresponding Window:MouseButtonDown(). This can occur if the mouse button is clicked while over the window, but released after the mouse has moved off the window. Use Window:MouseTrapOn() to direct all MouseEvents to this window.

member.name: M:VO.Window.MouseDrag(XSharp.__Usual)
member.summary: Provide a method that is invoked when a mouse with one or more buttons clicked is moved in the window. Important! This is a callback method used by X#. Normally, it should not be called in your application code.
member.param: The MouseEvent object containing information on the location and state of the buttons when the mouse was dragged.

member.name: M:VO.Window.MouseMove(XSharp.__Usual)
member.summary: Provide a method that is invoked when the mouse is moved in the window. Important! This is a callback method used by X#. Normally, it should not be called in your application code.
member.param: The MouseEvent object containing information on the location of the mouse when it was moved.
member.remarks: This event occurs when the mouse is moved with no mouse buttons clicked.

member.name: M:VO.Window.MouseTrapOff
member.summary: Disable the window from trapping MouseEvents generated outside itself.

member.name: M:VO.Window.MouseTrapOn
member.summary: Enable this window to trap MouseEvents generated outside itself.
member.remarks: Turn mouse trapping off before disabling or deactivating this window; otherwise, other windows cannot receive MouseEvents.

member.name: M:VO.Window.Move(XSharp.__Usual)
member.summary: Provide a method that is invoked when the window is moved (either by the user or by the application). Important! This is a callback method used by X#. Normally, it should not be called in your application code.
member.param: The MoveEvent object that describes the window movement.

member.name: M:VO.Window.MoveTo(XSharp.__Usual)
member.summary: Move the current pen to a point on the window's canvas area.
member.param: The position of the pen, in canvas coordinates.
member.returns: A point representing the previous location of the pen, in canvas coordinates.
member.remarks: The pen location may not be remembered between event handlers.

member.name: M:VO.Window.PaintBoundingBox(XSharp.__Usual,XSharp.__Usual)
member.summary: Paint a rectangular area in the window using a specified painting method.
member.param: The bounding box (group or character box) representing the window area to be painted, in canvas coordinates.
The constant that represents how the window area is painted:
Description
Fills the entire rectangle using the currently selected brush. This is the default.
Frames the entire rectangle using the currently selected pen
Inverts the entire rectangle

member.name: M:VO.Window.PostInit
member.summary: Implement customized initialization code for the window.
member.remarks: This method is used to customize the initialization code for a window. The customized initialization code will not be overridden by the Window Editor's default initialization code. A call to PostInit() is automatically generated at the end of the Init() method. You can customize the code generation by changing the [PostInitCall] and [PostInit] sections in your CAVOWED.TPL file. Note that PreInit() is always called prior to PostInit().

member.name: M:VO.Window.PreInit
member.summary: Implement customized initialization code for the window.
member.remarks: This method is used to customize the initialization code for a window. The customized initialization code will not be overridden by the Window Editor's default initialization code. A call to PreInit() is automatically generated at the beginning of the Init() method. You can customize the code generation by changing the [PreInitCall] and [PreInit] sections in your CAVOWED.TPL file. Note that only class variables are accessible in the PreInit() method, no window controls are visible until the PostInit() method itself is called.

member.name: M:VO.Window.PreMenuCommand
member.summary: Process menu events before the normal MenuCommand method is called. Important! This is a callback method used by X#. Normally, it should not be called in your application code.
member.remarks: This method can be written at the Window level to process menu commands. The window:PreMenuCommand( ) method will be called if it exists to process menu events before the normal MenuCommand( ) methods are called. The method must return a logic – TRUE – If you have processed the MenuCommand. FALSE – If you want the normal MenuCommand to run as well.

member.name: M:VO.Window.Print(XSharp.__Usual)
member.summary: Print the contents of the window.
member.param: The PrintingDevice object that will receive the output. If omitted, the default printer driver is used.
member.returns: TRUE if successful; otherwise, FALSE.

member.name: M:VO.Window.QueryClose(XSharp.__Usual)
member.summary: Provide a method that is invoked just before the window closes to confirm if the application really wants to close the window. Important! This is a callback method used by X#. Normally, it should not be called in your application code. If you reimplement this method in your subclass, it is recommended that you first call SUPER:QueryClose() within the method to obtain its default behavior.
member.param: An empty event required to maintain the protocol that all event handlers have exactly one event as their argument.
member.returns: You must return TRUE if the window is to be closed; otherwise, return FALSE.
member.remarks: When a user tries to close an application by selecting the Close menu command from a system menu (or by using another method to end the session), the system calls each window's QueryClose() event handler.
member.example:
This example displays a message box to confirm that a user wants to quit the application. If a user chooses YES, TRUE is returned (otherwise, FALSE is returned).
METHOD QueryClose(oEvent) CLASS TopAppWindow oTB := TextBox{SELF, "Quit", "Do you really want to quit?"} oTB:TYPE := BOXICONQUESTIONMARK + BUTTONYESNO IF (oTB:Show() = BOXREPLYYES) RETURN TRUE // Quit application. ELSE RETURN FALSE // Don't quit the application. END

member.name: M:VO.Window.RegisterTimer(XSharp.__Usual,XSharp.__Usual)
member.summary: Register a timer method to be invoked for the window.
member.param: Time interval, in seconds, between calls to the Timer() method of the window.
Logical value indicating if the timer is called just once (TRUE), or multiple times (FALSE). If omitted, the default is FALSE.

member.name: M:VO.Window.RePaint

member.name: M:VO.Window.RepaintBoundingBox(XSharp.__Usual)

member.remarks: This method should be avoided within an Expose() event handler. If it is used, make sure the application does not fall into an infinite loop.

member.name: M:VO.Window.RichEditUndoLost(XSharp.__Usual)

member.name: M:VO.Window.Scroll(XSharp.__Usual,XSharp.__Usual,XSharp.__Usual)
member.summary: Scroll a rectangular area in the window a specified amount, in a specified direction, and optionally clip the area when scrolled.
member.param: The dimension representing the amount to move the rectangular scroll area (relative to its origin). Positive width values scroll to the right while negative width values scroll to the left. In addition, positive height values scroll upwards while negative height values scroll downwards.
The bounding box representing the rectangular window area, in canvas coordinates. If omitted, the default is the canvas area of the screen.
Indicates whether to clip the rectangular area when scrolled. TRUE clips the area; FALSE does not. If omitted, the default is TRUE.
member.remarks: The clip region is an area that can receive output from the system.

member.name: M:VO.Window.SetBackgroundBrush(XSharp.__Usual)
member.summary: Set the background brush used to paint the window.
member.param: The new brush to use. The default is COLOR_3DSHADOW.

member.name: M:VO.Window.SetExStyle(XSharp.__Usual,XSharp.__Usual)
member.summary: Set the extended style of a window.
member.param: The extended style to set.
A logical value. TRUE turns the style on, FALSE turns it off.

member.name: M:VO.Window.SetFocus
member.summary: Set the keyboard focus to this window.

member.name: M:VO.Window.SetStyle(XSharp.__Usual,XSharp.__Usual)
member.summary: Set the styles for the window.
member.param: The X# style constant or Windows API style constant to set.
Logical value indicating whether the style should be enabled (TRUE) or disabled(FALSE). If omitted, the default is TRUE.
member.returns: Numeric value representing the X# style constants or Windows API style constants enabled for the window.

member.name: M:VO.Window.Show(XSharp.__Usual)
member.summary: Display this window.
member.param: The constant that represents how the window is shown. Valid values are:
Description
Shows the window centered within its owner window. If the owner is the desktop, the window is centered on the screen.
Shows the window initially as an icon.
Shows the window on its owner, in a size chosen by the owner, but the window remains inactive. That is, the window that previously had focus retains that focus.

Shows the window on its owner, in a size chosen by the owner. If the owner is the desktop, the window appears quite large but may not fill the whole desktop. You can control the window's size precisely, if you want, with Window:Size and Window:Origin. This is the default.
Shows the window at the maximum size allowed by its owner. If the owner is the desktop, the window occupies the whole desktop.

member.name: M:VO.Window.ShowBalloonTrayTip(XSharp.__Usual,XSharp.__Usual,XSharp.__Usual,XSharp.__Usual,XSharp.__Usual,XSharp.__Usual)
member.summary: Display a balloon tip for an icon in the tray that is associated with this window.
member.param: The icon to be displayed in the tray.
The unique ID of the icon (between 1 and 8000).
The heading to be displayed in the balloon. This title appears in boldface above the text. It can have a maximum of 63 characters.
The text to be displayed in the balloon. In Shell version 5 and above, the maximum size is 128 charecters. Below Shell version 5, the maximum is 64 charecters.

The length of time to display the balloon before it is removed if it is not dismissed by the user.
The system enforces minimum and maximum timeout values. dwTimeout values that are too large are set to the maximum value and values that are too small default to the minimum value.
This is set in milliseconds.

Flags that can be set to add an icon to a balloon ToolTip.
In version 5.0 of Shell and above it is possible to place an icon to the left of the title.
Valid values are:
Description
An error icon.
An information icon.
No icon.
A warning icon.
Shell Version 6.0. Reserved.
Shell Version 6.0. Do not play the associated sound.

member.name: M:VO.Window.SizeText(XSharp.__Usual)
member.summary: Determine the space needed to print a string on the window in the current font.
member.param: The string to be printed.
member.returns: A dimension representing the space required to print the string on this window using the current font.

member.name: M:VO.Window.StatusMessage(XSharp.__Usual,XSharp.__Usual)
member.summary: Display a message in a window's status bar.
member.param: The hyperlabel containing a description (HyperLabel:Description) for the status message.

The constant value indicating the type and priority of the message to be displayed on the status bar. The highest priority message (MESSAGEMENU) always takes precedence over and replaces lower priority messages.
Description
Priority 4 (Highest priority): A message associated with a menu selection.
Priority 3: An error message.
Priority 2: A message associated with a control. This is the default.
Priority 1 (Lowest priority): The default message displayed on the status bar; stored whenever a higher priority message takes precedence and redisplayed when no other messages take priority.

member.name: M:VO.Window.Update
member.summary: Update the client area of the specified window.
member.remarks: This method utilizes the Windows API UpdateWindow() function which updates the client area of the specified window by sending a WM_PAINT message to the window. The message is sent directly to the window procedure of the specified window, thus bypassing the application queue. The Window:Update() method is automatically called upon when terminating the Expose(). This method should not be used within an Expose() event handler.

member.name: M:VO.Window.VerticalScroll(XSharp.__Usual)
member.summary: Provide a method that is invoked when a vertical scroll bar is scrolled. Important! This is a callback method used by X#. Normally, it should not be called in your application code.
member.param: The ScrollEvent object that describes the scroll type and new position.
member.remarks: The default behavior for this event handler is to update the thumb position; this can be changed using your own implementation of the handler. This event handler only works for HorizontalScrollBar and WindowHorizontalScrollBar objects. If the application has horizontal scroll bars, use a HorizontalScrollBar event handler.

member.name: M:VO.Window.VerticalSlide(XSharp.__Usual)
member.summary: Provide a method that is invoked when a vertical slider's thumb is dragged either by the mouse or the keyboard. Important! This is a callback method used by X#. Normally, it should not be called in your application code.
member.param: The SliderEvent object that describes which vertical slider's thumb was dragged.

member.name: M:VO.Window.VerticalSpin(XSharp.__Usual)
member.summary: Provide a method that is invoked when a vertical spinner is spun. Important! This is a callback method used by X#. Normally, it should not be called in your application code.
member.param: The SpinnerEvent object that describes which vertical spinner was spun.

member.name: M:VO._CodeBlock.Eval
member.summary: Evaluate a runtime-compiled code block.
member.returns: A value whose data type depends on the value(s) passed to the code block, as well as the particular code block.
member.remarks: This method is called if the Eval() function is used to evaluate a runtime-compiled code block.
member.example:
Create a runtime-compiled code block and evaluate it using the _CodeBlock:Eval() method and the Eval() function:
LOCAL cb cb := &("{|x| x * x}"} ? cb:EVAL(5) // 25 ? EVAL(cb,5) // 25

member.name: M:VO._CodeBlock.#ctor
member.summary: Create a _CodeBlock object.
member.param: The number of parameters the runtime code block expects.
The binary string representing the code that makes up the code block.
member.remarks: This method is only to be called by the X# macro system.
